This beer was above expectations. I really liked it alot. 
A nice deep brown/red body with beige head. First a funny smell of of possibly liquor and yeast. Then an aroma of coffee and a lot of dark chocolate. Complex taste which was exciting. Some vinous or champagne taste with some sweetness in after-taste. You do notice the high alcohol percentage in the taste. The bitterness became more prominent when I poured out the bottom layer.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2011 Cloudy dark red-brown with a creamy stable head, a middle, but a little bit oily body,  hoppy, nice carbonation, roasted malts, coffee and hints of bitter chocolate, bitter aftertaste
Deep red brown.  A bit of musty smell, some dark fruit, mild biscuit/toast.  Mild dark fruits, bread, biscuit, mild yeast.  Relatively dry finish.

Bottle at home. Deep reddish brown, gushing tan head that slowly diminishes. Funny nose - I get some real sour fruit and slightly off esters. I have a feeling this may be skunked :( will re-rate. Palate is spiced with figs and some raisins, dry grassy finish. Meh.

bottle in a glass that is not appropriate - pours an opaque and dark brown with tan head.  Lots of sediment.  Aroma is akin to wildberries or small dark fruit (name escapes me).  Definite "basement aromas."  taste is sweet.  Finish is almost numbing to the tongue in a slow fashion.  A very organic and introspective beer.  YUM!

33cl bottle from "Il regno di Gambrinus". Served into a snifter. Pours a dirty dark orange/light brown with a big fluffy yellowish head. Lots and lots of carbonation bubblese streaming from the bottom of the glass. Wow this is a complex beer, there are just too many aromas to describe. I can feel dark fruits, orange, grapes, caramel, grassy hops, caramel and a quite strong alchool presence as well. In the mouth it goes down really smoth thanks a very lively carbonation, After adding the yeast, I can find a totally different beer. There is definitely more sweetness, the malt backbone is more subtle, and there is a lot less alchool presence. Overall, this is a great drinking experience that I will certainly enjoy more times.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2014 Original rating August 2011: Bottle. The aroma here is outstanding. Sharp, fruity, a hint of orange. Very nice. Dark brown colour. Nice fruity flavour, some banana, not too bitter. A little spice on the mouth, then finishes dry and smooth. Excellent stuff. 4.2
Bottle aged since 2011 rated in 2014: Loads of dried fruit, still has a sharp and a touch of orange element. The booze has come out a bit to play. 4

bottle, dark reddish/brown colour with very nice and foamy white and stable head. Smell: dried fruits, plums, chocolate, roasted malts. Taste: dried fruits, has some stoute alike taste, black chocolate, coffee. Very complex beer, just great. Very cheap one as well, The beste price-quality beer in the world in my opinion.

A - Spicy, caramel and fruity
A - Dark brown and hazy
T - Light sweetness with a controlled dry bitter finish
P - medium to full with a bit of a harsh carbonation
O - Really good...but not the greatness I had hoped

Poured from 330mL bottle a hazy reddish brown color with lasting beige head with fine lacing.  Aromas of malt and yeast.  Taste is moderately sweet with some bitter notes.  A very fine Dubbel ale with moderate body and carbonation.
Incredibly smooth and drinkable, despite higher alcohol content. I just wish I had the proper glass.

The beer pours a hazy brown color with a decent-sized tan head. The aroma is heavy on the raisins and cherries with some nice brown sugar notes. I also get some yeast notes. The flavor is not as fruit as the aroma. I get some raisins and plum notes, but what is more prevalent is the toffee from the malt. The yeast is also present in the flavor. There is some brown sugar flavor but the beer is fairly dry overall. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A world classic beer that never disappoints.

Bittery goodness. But this one makes me want to try the Tripel.
(This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)
Dark caramel taste and pours in a nice dark colour. Very sweet and well balanced dark beer, highly enjoyable.

Reddish brown with a medium head.  Aroma is dominated by sugar and yeast, with a little fruit and bread.  Taste is sweet, with some caramel toffee flavor, but not overpowering due to the alcohol and carbonation.  A really great beer, as expected from the masters of the style.

330ml bottle.  Poured a nice reddish brown with a foamy head.  The taste is malty with a medium sweetness start and a light bitter finish .  Tastes like it is slightly stronger than 7%.  Overall, it is a nice Trappist Ale that will not disappoint .

33cl Bottle from Bierzwerg.  Appearance is slightly reddish brown color with light, bubbly head - great lacing.  Aroma is sugary malts, dried fruit and yeast.  Taste is corresponding with sugar, malts, fruit dominant.  Flavors move into a doughy yeast on to a smooth, semi-dry finish.  Palate is medium-bodied, soft texture, and fizzy carbonation.  A classic in the style.
330ml bottle @ William K. Tennispalatsi, Helsinki. Originally rated on 18.1.2010. Classic trappist dubbel, nicely balanced and tasty.
Pours dark copper with a beige head. Aroma is dark caramel, dried fruit, plum and raisin. Flavour is dark caramel, light alcohol and dried fruit.
Dark brown body and tan head. Fruity, sweet, raisins and some dark sugar aroma. Taste slitghty sweet and sour. Smooth medium body. A good beer.

Pours a reddish brown with a dark beige head.  
Smells fruity, floral, leaves, cereal.
Taste pretty sweet.
Palate is fruity, light bodied, slightly bitter/tart, lively carbonation, long sweet finish.
Pours dark brown with foamy head. Chocolate and raisins aroma, with some alcohol. Has a sour taste at the end, with a thick body. One of the best dubbels, I prefer it to St bernardus 8

Bottle from Presporska pivoteka, Bratislava. 0.33l bottle,Dark brown color with small beige head. Aroma, fruity, sweet malt. Taste, slightly sweet, siome fruits, prunes, cherries, maybe,spices. Bittersweet finish. alcohol is well present. Very good beer.
(Tap 5/7-2011) < mobile > low lasting head, dark brown color, smooth taste

Bottle 33cl, pours nice with large! off white head, nice red dark brown! ..... the aroma is nice fresh ,resin, dark fruit,brown sugar.... flavor is brown sugar, bit alcohol...thin body... nice mouthful...... :)

33ml bottle poured in to Trappist glass. Nice looking beer. Poured a dark brown with reddish tones and a half inch bubbly off white head that stayed for the duration. Nice lacing. Light bodied with a smooth front end and a pleasing bitter finish that lingers for some time. Taste is mild burnt sugars, malt, fruits, with some woodiness. Alcohol is hidden but noticeable. Aroma is consistent with the taste. I enjoyed this one and found it refreshing on this hot day in Regina.

Pours a nice mahogany color with an off-white foamy head. Smell of yeast, sweet malt, and dried fruits. Flavor is more of the same, with a distinct taste of brown sugar and walnuts. Mouthfeel is smooth and rich for the style. Nice long, lingering finish. I can taste this for a while after Im done! Excellent beer. Westmalle never disappoints.

Westmalle dubbel. Goblet poured at akkurat... Pours a mostly opaque  
caramel mahogany pour with a fluffy cloudy white head... Aroma  
consists of dark fruits (raisins and dates) with some brown sugar  
malty aspects with some caramel thrown in for good measure... Flavors  
are sweet, malty with a big emphasis in dark fruits and a brown sugary  
balance. Smooth medium body, sweeter through the middle and tailend  
while finishing on a slight bitter note. Complementing and quite nice  
for the style.
7/4/7/4/15
I dont really like abbey dubbel beers so the score is a bit low. I do like the colour of this beer.
One of the best balanced beers I know and probably the best Abbey Dubbel Ive had (so far (1178 now)). Brown colored. Nice smell, good taste. Very good carbonation. Very balanced, lovely beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown/red with a large beige creamy head. Aroma is malty, dark fruit, raisin, anise, brown sugar, spicy and sweet. Taste is complex and lasting with notes of dried fruit. Sweet and slightly dry bitter after-taste.
Very good beer, very good Dubbel. As compared with Chimay, Westmalle is less fruity, but more hop bitter and this is what I like. Depends on your taste, but everyone will like it.

Pours deep brown, reddish notes with an enormous cream coloured head leaving good lace as it subsides. Spicy, bready gingerloaf and dry chocolate aromas. Nutty roastiness, dates and raisins as well. And then theres licorice and butter, cloves and plum sauce. Lots going on.
Initially there sourness and then a rush of all that tastes brown. Chocolate sponge cake and astringent wine. Light sweetness  going on along with generous bubbly mouthfeel. A lot to love about this beer.

Pours dark brown with rusty colored highlights and a beige head that fades more than I thought it would.  Aroma of raisin, wheat, red wine, dust, mushrooms, cinnamon, and maybe toast.  Complex aroma, wonderful yeast.  Flavor is significantly drier than expected with some raisin and caramel, wood, earthy hops, dust, and light red wine.  Finishes with a surprisingly assertive bitterness and  earthy, dusty flavor, like nearly burned toast.  Medium bodied, high carbonation, the mouthfeel just doesnt seem to have the creaminess it should.  Good, but its just too dry for me.  I wonder if the bottle is old.

Bottle in trappist glass. Rich and dark in color with persistent, yeasty head. Aroma of raisins, vanilla, bananas, fresh bread, nail polish remover. Flavor very bready, a little sour; teabag flavor and puckering tongue makes me believe flavorwise, its a little off, unfortunately; the bitterness is almost overwhelming, and while Im not an expert in dubbels, I havent had one quite like this. Great aroma, but ultimately disappointing. What does one have to do these days to ensure that the beer he buys is going to be in good condition? Im getting very frustrated.

Very nice, still left me a little underwhelmed compared to their excellent Tripel. Pours a reddish brown with a big slightly off white head. Looks great. Aroma is a touch of malt, lots of brown sugar and raisins and dark dried fruit. Taste is very balanced, with roasted malt, lots of spices, obviously brown sugar and raisins. Good level of carbonation and a full body, long and enjoyable aftertaste.
33cl bottle. A rusty red. Red wine like aroma. Subtle chocolate with some dark fruit esters. Has a small spicy and dry finish.

33cl bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee, best by 27/07/12.  Pours deep brown color with an off-white head and some lacing.  Aroma is malty, dark fruit, raisin, anise, brown sugar.  Medium body on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malty, a little boozy, with a light bitter finish.  I could drink this every day were it not for the price.

Bottle; Pour is murky brown with a nice, typical, frothy, fine bubbled beige head that retains well; spotty lacing into this tulip. The nose is terrific, as expected, as well. Spicy sweetbreads, caramel, brown sugars, raisins really. This malt forward brew is on the easy side to drink, as well. There is a bit of cream from the head ; the spiciness tends to linger a bit, there is a noticeable and general sweetness present of course; while the hop presence is mild at best. My only fault is that this brew, or my bottle, feels slightly thin on the tongue; I give the edge to St. Bernardus.

Sampled at Texas Beerfest. Pours a cloudy brown with a medium creamy light tan head that lasts awhile leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is brown sugar and raisin malt. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet malt and brown sugar and caramel. Easy to drink hiding the alcohol well. A very good Abbey dubbel.

Sampler at Øl og matfestivalen.
Dark brown/red, offwhite bubbling head. Malty aroma with spices, raisins, fruit. Full bodied with a rich taste of dried fruit, chocolate, sugar. Good complexity and balance

Dark brown pour with a healthy off-white head; fine but visible sediment gives a hazy appearance. Impressive fruity bouquet; berry coulis, sour cherry, apple, toffee and dates. On the tougue they meld with biscuity malt, wood barrel and vinous flavours. Bitey hop bitterness in the tail, with quite a bit of residual tartness and bitterness. More carbonation than Id expect from a Trappist ale, though it doesnt detract much. Right up there with the best dubbels.

Das Dubbel beginnt mild malzig, wobei sich dieser Ton mit der Zeit deutlich verstärken wird. Sehr voluminös breitet sich ein süß und rauchig wirkender Ton aus, deutlich würzig, aber nicht sehr stark. Das Bier scheint sich bewusst auf diese Töne zu konzentrieren, ohne überladen zu wirken, was zweifelsohne gelingt. Die nun stärker gewordene Malzigkeit ist nun der Mittelpunkt des Bieres, kräftig, dennoch weich, das Bier bleibt süffig. Wieder ist das Bier kurz alkoholisch, aber keinesfalls störend. Gelungenes und empfehlenswertes Bier. 	 
Test vom 7.10.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,12,13,13,12,13 - 12,60
Bottle in an Amsterdam bar.  Brown pour with off whit head.  Aromas of malt and dark fruit.  Flavor of fruits, raisins, plums.  Medium carbonation.  Nice balance.

Took my time for this one. It is more or less my default trappist, the benchmark I put other trappist beers against. Where I grew up, on Sundays you would see people drinking this beer almost everywhere, often -blasphemy!- with grenadine syrup, a "tradition" that luckily is dying out. 
Dark brown colour, reddish brown glow. Firm beige creamy head. Aroma of malts, dried fruits, spicy yeast and a touch of candy sugar. Flavour is rather sweet. Malty, dried fruits, molasses, only very slight hops, yeast, spices (cloves and light liquorice), surprisingly dry for such a sweetish hefty beer. Some burnt malts bitterness in the finish. Very enjoyable.
(At home, from 33cL bottle. For my 222nd rating)

33 cl bottle.  Pours a light cola brown with a very big very light tan head that sticks around for a long time and leaves a lot of lacing on the glass.  The aroma is raisin, plum, some light licorice, some spicy yeast, and very light alcohol.  The initial taste is raisin and plum.  This then goes into some very light molasses with some spicy yeast on the finish.  No alcohol in the taste.  Pretty dry overall.  Light body.  Medium carbonation.  Overall a very enjoyable beer.

Pours dark ruby brown with big white head, which dissipates to a small white head. Excellent bubbles and lacing as with tripel. Nose is very good. Not quite as complex as Orval but has the same sweet perfumed sherbert overtones. Dominant aromas are stewed plums, prunes and raisins. Taste is slightly underwhelming after aroma, but is a nice balance of prunes, raisins, chocolate and a bit of sweet bitterness on the finish.  Grows on the tongue as you drink it revealing new harmonies. Also have to say this would be a fantastic food accompaniment to stewed meat with dark fruit like stewed beef and prunes or Moroccan lamb tagine.

330 ml bottle thanks to weihenweizen, pours a murky brown with a fizzy off white head, aroma is sweet with notes of dark fruit mixed in with a hint of booze, the flavor is very sweet with caramel and raisin, has a fizzy dry finish, pretty good stuff.

bottle at Fire: Pours hazy, reddish amber. fizzy, carbonated sand head. Jack Daniels, fruit punch, plum, dates on the nose. T- Ripe plums, esters, dates. light body with high carbonation. Astringent finish. Dry and refreshing.
Reddish brown with a large head. Lots of mixed dried fruits, raisins, some chocolate, brown sugar and a slight spiciness. Initially sweet but goes over to show some acidity and ends rather dry.

Westmalle Dubbel, sampled on draught. Colour was dark brown to red. Head was white with big and small bubbles. Aroma has darker fruits, kandy sugar and barley. Loads of herbs present as wel as some plums, blackberries and raisins. Flavour is bitter fresh, with a small start of sweetness. Looks great, really bubbly in its original glass. Mouthfeel is subtle and well balanced.

Bottle 33 cl from Systembolaget Passagen, Stockholm. Poured dark copper wit reddish tones in colour and creamy tan head. Quite malty and boozy aroma but weet, slightly burnt brown sugar and dark fruits fortunately takes  over in aroma. Flavour a bit bitter with dried dark fruits and sweet malty notes pushing through. Very pleasant aftertaste.
Pours a foamy, lacing tan head with a copper-brown body.  Aromas of raisins and dark dried fruit.  Flavors are raisin, dark dried fruit, brown sugar.  Finish is dry with a lasting dark sweetness.

0.33l bottle. Pours a hazy deep brown body with a nice light-tanned head leaving small lacing. Aroma is surprisingly fruity and the first thing that distinctively came to mind was a Christmas soda from Norway. Also notes of cherries, strawberries and dark caramel. Medium bodied has a oily texture and the carbonation level is medium +. Flavors are at first nice, caramel-sweet and fruity with notes of strawberries, cherries, raisin? and oak. Then in the end it turns slightly bitter-sour leaving a mild and long lasting bitter aftertaste. A really nice dubbel from the monk-masters.

33cl bottle.
Decent white head.  Slightly hazy amber colour.  A good Trappist beer
Bottle. An amber to brown colour with a tanned head. The aroma is sweet and fruity and a little malty.  A very smooth taste with some hops and yeast. Maybe some caramel. .

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2011 Appearance: Bottle into Westmalle trappist glass. Pours a hazy, dark burgundy with a moderate mocha-coloured head which fades within a couple of minutes. A lot of floaty stuff is present. Aroma: Winey, sweet and grassy with a sour citrusyness to it and a touch of spices. Taste: Candied sugar, spices and a prominent toasty malt profile. Palate: Creamy smooth, unoffensive and agreeable with the mouth. A bit on the watery side though. Overall: Pretty nice, but not as good as the Tripel which is one of my favorite beers. Still worth seeking out though.
redish brown colour with strong head. notes of mellon and some fruttiness. medium body sweet with dryish grassy like finish. malty. great dubbel

25 cl.
fine head, Dark
Dark spicey nose wit a strange vegetable note, caramel.
Full body and nice length
taste is caramel, chockolate and a light bitterness
A powerfull beer but not with out flaws.

Fantastic aroma, so sweet it is almost like fruit candy. raisin, banana, Very nice head too, uneven. The top of the taste has that fruitiness (banana, cloves) while the bottom and aftertaste are more stubborn and hoppy. Beautiful beer.

(11.2oz bottle) Pours dark brown-dark mahogany when held up to the light with a khaki head.  Aroma has candied sugar, dark fruit, and sherry-like notes.  Taste is a sweet malt backbone with a little sour and some hops on the end.  Thin bodied with a creamy texture.  Finish is a bit dry, but smooth. Some effervesence.   Not the best trappist beer out there, but still a very nice beer.

SCHIUMA:
color nocciola, fine , media presenza a abbastanza duratura
COLORE:
marrone scuro con riflessi ambrati, velata

INTENSITA / FINEZZA / AROMA
piuttosto profumata, con sentori fruttati di lievito, malto tostato con note di caramello, una punta vinosa alcolica.
GUSTO / RETROGUSTO / PERSISTENZA
entra combattendo fra il dolce e un fruttato acidulo; la lotta dura poco e lascia posto ad un amaro piuttosto evidente, dato più che altro dai malti tostati. Termina rimanendo legata alle note amare. Si nota un po di alcol e qualche sapore metallico sospettoso.

CORPO / CARBONATAZIONE / CONSISTENZA
corpo medio, ben carbonata, fluida in bocca e molto bevibile.
PER dirla tutta, mi aspettavo una birra del tutto diversa, con profumi e sapori proiettati maggiormente sul fronte del dolce-fruttato, mentre di fatto risulta essere una birra piuttosto amara per il genere, non tanto per i luppoli bensì per la tostatura. Daltra parte, al naso e in bocca è piuttosto dinamica, si riconoscono varie sfumature in continua evoluzione; rimane qualche nota metallica non prevista, ma nel complesso  è molto godibile, con un tasso alcolico ben nascosto. per concludere:  non mi ha convinto al 100%.

750ml bottle.   Pours a hazy reddish brown color with a thick tan head that shrinks to a solid cap.  Smell is spicy and fruity with plums, dates, raisons, and a faint nutty smell, along with a touch of breadiness, as well as alcohol.  The flavors are quite complex and less sweet than many Dubbels, withb the dark fruits that subside into a smoother maltiness through the finish. Nice yeasty mustiness lingers in the aftertaste.
Mouthfeel is rich and creamy with a medium body. Finishes dry and crisp.

Bottle.
Amber brown color with a nice amount of tan head.  Brown sugar, dark fruit, and nice malty aromas.  Near perfect mouthfeel for the style, very smooth.  Some hop bite, spicy yeast, caramel, and slightly sweet flavors.  Just delicious.
Dark beer with a large forthy head. A malty aroma with a hint of chocolate. Definately taste the carbonation in this beer.
Basic Belgian. Nothing here makes me want to add it to my fridge or my cellar.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep ruby brown with a lacy, thick, light tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, spicy yeast, caramel, a little vanilla, and light hops.  Flavor a very nice blend of these, with the dark fruits and yeast sticking out.  Silky, smooth texture.  A great Trappist beer.

draft @ Little Delirium, Brussels.
Cuivre, mousse beige.
Arôme de fruits noirs, sucre brun, le tout allant vers le cassis et figue.
En bouche, une bonne double avec le profile typique de cette bière. Fruité; figue et prune avec sucre brun, levure et un côté houblonné qui est plus dominant.
Facile à boire, solide dans son concept et fidèle à la tradition.

Saboreada el 2 Mar/11 en una copa Cáliz (Westmalle). Color Siena tostado, cuerpo turbio. Coronada en beige con una espuma tupida, de burbuja pequeña, persistente hasta el final. Amplio encaje. Intensa sensación de aroma malteado, levadura y  baja lupulización. Cuerpo medio, carbonatación baja muy bien equilibrada. Un muy suave y seco amargor en boca. Percepción de alto nivel alcoholico bajo la lengua, fresco. Sútil chocolate en el retrogusto. Una cerveza sorprendente aunque no sea mi favorita en su Estilo. Adecuada para un trago largo y pausado.
Enjoyed on 3/2/11 in a Chalice glass. Burnt sienna color, cloudy body. Headed beige close foam, small bubbles, carried on ´til the end. Wide lacing. High sensation of malty aroma, yeast & low hoppiness. Medium body, low carbonation very well balanced. Very soft & dry bitterness in mouth. Perception of high level of alcohol under your tongue, crisp. Subtle chocolate on the aftertaste. Surprising beer even not being my favourite one of the style. Suggested for a long & paused drink.
Nice super dark beer with a smooth taste. Wasnt expecting the nice dark kick

bottle; dark red-brown cloudy with large tan head; aroma-sweet, caramel, molasses, spice, dried fruits-raisins; taste-moderate sweetness, carbonation and bitterness. Great beer, almost like some sweet sherry.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2014 Bouteille 330 ml. 7%. Merci Jean-Ben. Couleur brune voilée. Mousse beige. Arôme de fruits mûrs, cerises, malt. En bouche, fruits, cerises de terre, malt, un peu de caramel, houblon. Finale assez sèche, avec une amertume surprenante pour une double belge. Très Bonne.

0.33L bottle in Brussels. Pours a very nice nut brown amber. Smells of dark fruit - cherry, fig, grape/prune - caramel malt, and very light banana. Mouthfeel is very smooth - initially finely carbonated and later feeling thick and velvety. Flavor alternates between a slight hop bittersweet tart and deep fruit, caramel, and brown sugar. Very finely balanced in every discernible respect. Finish is exceptionally smooth. Quite clearly an exceptional brew.
Bottle. Pours deep amber brown with tan head. Malt yeast aroma, malt yeast taste, a very very fine dubbel.

Big deep dark amber pour, not much on top, head was prettty thin, but still appealing. Smell was a massive caramel, malty sweetness. On to the taste, and well, very malty sweetness as the nose, but a nice dry fizziness to finish it off. At first I was not that impressed, but that was based on the hype, but as I drank a few more sips, it warms up to you and the fizziness on the end cleans the pallate and your ready for more. A true classic.
Very dark red body, off white head. Citric aroma full of fruits and caramel. Sweet flavour, apricot, kiwi.

21 Mar 2011
really dark ruby, clear, thin, rocky tan head.
soft nose. yeasty bananas.
med/thin body and very fizzy. almost explodes in your mouth.
this is almost a "technically" perfect beer w/ no personality.
yeast isnt robust, malt isnt big. there is some coffee bitterness but otherwise, just fizzy bland dubbel.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2016 Dark, coffee colour with excellent head retention and lace. The nose is slightly elusive, but banana comes through with a little bit of apple/pear in the background. Nice lemon yoghurt, spice and yeast finish. Big structure, creamy/zingy texture and a refreshing finish.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: dominant sweet malt with some caramel, raw, brown sugar, hint of herbs, touch of hops, medium body, slightly creamy, nice dubbel, tap@café/restaurant across the monetary/brewery: similar to the bottle version but more balanced & bit richer & creamier (rated for tap version which is preferable) /////////////////// Had this one again, disappointed me a bit. Will see if it will deliver next time around. Quite cheap this one @ supermarket.
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a large head.  Aroma is raisin malt, some yeast present as well.  Rasin malt finish.  Fruity malt on the aftertaste.  Lots of carbonation.

Pours a cloudy brown with a hint of orange when held up to a light. The thin tan head gently laces the glass.  A high level of carbonation results in a constant stream of bubbles.  Pleasant malt, spicy fruit, and prune aromas.  Full bodied with a rich creamy mouthfeel.The spicy Belgian yeast character burst on the tongue accompanied by sweet malt, prune, and raisin notes.
Excellent dubbel, Im always pleased to find it sold at a pub where theres nothing I havent tried.

Bottle sample purchased at Zyn Calgary. Pours a dark brown with a slight ruby hue. Nice fizzy white head, and leaves decent cascading lace. The aroma is not super strong but it is nice, and of dark fruits and a little spice. The taste is just amazing, caramel, fruit, spice, maybe a little vanilla. Just a wonderful brew.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2011 I have had this in the states but thought it was just blah. But having it fresh, albeit out of the bottle, a couple hours from where it is brewed made all the difference. 
 Poured a deep mahogany into a chalice. Great big off-white head that slowly dissipated leaving beautiful lacing on the sides of the glass. 
Malty aroma, little fruity and very pleasant. 
Maltiness stays from the aroma. Slight alcohol taste. Balanced well though. Taste of raisins, a bit sweet with a bit of bitterness which might be from the carbonation.
Tastes thinner than it looks and finishes drier than one would think. All due to the carbonation, which is expectedly high.
I prefer the Dubbel as opposed to the Tripel as it seems the sweetness of this one makes it more palatable to me. The lower alcohol also helps with the drinkability, but this isnt something you would want to drink all day long. Especially on a hot day.



Just had a 1993 version. Man does this one hold up well. Might want to cellar some for a while.

Cloudy dark brown pour, thick head that lingers a while.  Large bubbles in the head, but theyre mostly the same size, giving a non-random effect on the side of the glass.  Malty sweetness on the nose.  I cant place what the sweetness remind me of other than Dr. Pepper, but it isnt nearly that sweet.  The bubbles in the beer itself are much smaller than Id have guessed from the head (but maybe thats where all the CO2 went).  Good flavor, malt, maybe plum or a darker fruit but not what I would call fruity.  The taste lasts a while, but doesnt linger a long time.  I really like it, though Id love it more if the flavor exploded in your mouth rather than sliding in gracefully.
Bottle at Haymarket.  Amber with beige head.  Smells like chocolate covered raisins/ripe caramel apples with some brown sugar.  Lots more apple/caramel in taste.  Very smooth.  Memorable.

Pours a brownish red color.  Has a nice caramel smells with some roasted fig tree flavors.  Taste is a bit bitter and dry.  There are some nice caramel flavors with the roasted fig tree flavors popping up.  I like.

Clear deep red brown with a big beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is rather sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and bitter finish. Clearly not one of my favorites among the trappists. 210211

very enjoyable the more that my palate is starting to accept the more malty beers that would have been too sweet for me to enjoy. aroma is of sweet fruits and grain, taste is the same, brown color with a hint of amber. very easy to drink and enjoy.

Poured a dark brownish purple color.  Aromas of chocolate, yeast, plums, and raisins.  Taste has caramel, raisins and chocolate.  It is overall pretty sweet with some butterscotch candy notes.  Overall very smooth and tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 red brown colour, small head. smells of red fruit. looks very rich and dense.    moderate carbination with balanced flavour.  bit to dry dry with slight bitterness at the end. good finish but perhaps not long enough.
2nd and 3rd tasting. much better than initial tasting. notes of chocolate and coffee. very good.

330ml bottle. Rich creamy beige head that is full and thick. Dark brwon tea stain colour with aromas of raisins and berries. Full velvety texture with the flavour to match. Light spice flavour with a tongue tingling aftertaste. Good Belgian dubbel.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2012 One of the sources of great Belgian ales, just an awesome ale, heavy on the malty/dark fruit.
A big, robust Belgian dubbel. Tons of character form the Belgian yeast in this one. One of my first Trappist ales a few years ago.

Westmalle Dubbel comes in what I think is the coolest looking bottle I have yet seen in my beer reviewing. Something about it just suits the beer it contains. Maybe it is because my mental image of monks is a round body with no waist, then the collar of their robes, and then a thinner head sticking out.

I eventually settled on using an oversized Riedel white wine glass for Westmalle Dubbel and it worked out quite well.

The beer poured an extremely deep reddish brown that became ruby at the edges where all the light hitting the beer is seemingly absorbed into a black hole.

The head developed 2  3 fingers thick and almost impossibly dense and creamy. The head held fast at virtually the same level it poured for minutes after. I didnt notice any change until I started to drink the beer. Even as I let it warm up a few degrees the head only receded a small amount. This beer leaves copious amounts of fine Belgian lace on the glass.

My first sniffs revealed to me that the beer was too cold to be properly appreciated. I was strained to identify much. I waited several minutes for the beer to warm up a few degrees and tried again. Despite expecting some change  I was shocked at the difference. The aroma of the beer livened right up and unleashed a complex symphony of smells.

The conductor of this symphony is clearly the malts  they first great you to the performance and immediately make known their quality credentials. The malts smell a little sweet and bready with an undertone of caramel and toffee. Subsequent sniffs reveal dark cherry and plums. I can smell the slightest bit of muskiness which I would think is the unique Belgian yeast that Westmalle uses in all of its beers.

The taste  to continue the analogy  is like watching that same symphony from a different seat. New things are visible but this is still the same performance. I can again tell the malts form the backbone of this beer  they taste bold and a little bready. After I the dark fruit flavors finish I start to taste a few new things  light cocoa and very faint coffee. Filtering this through what I know about producing Westmalle Dubbel I am inclined to think this is from the kilned malts.

There is a sweetness to the beer as a whole  probably from the caramelized liquid syrup added. There is a bit of a dry finish with a warming alcohol sensation.

The mouthfeel is not too heavy but is definitely not thin. It has a creamy and smooth texture that goes down very easily. It is quite effervescent and if rolled in the mouth for a while you can feel the carbonation tingling.

Overall  this is an extremely well brewed beer. It all balances very well and is a great sipper  although gulps are not out of the question. This is getting 4 pints but it was extremely close to rounding up to 5.

Cold 11.2 oz btl into my Spiegelau snifter. Ridiculously drinkable. Goes down like a whisper, like the great Belgian masterpiece that it is. An easy-going, friendly beer - sort of how I imagine the monks that brew it to be.

750mm bottle from: mainbrew.com

Visual: Dark walnut reddish brown, off white head that doesnt last long. A bit murky, but appropriate for style. No Belgian lace like you get with Chimay.

Nose: Plum, dried figs, toffee, ethanol, burnt sugar.

Palate: Light to medium body, bright prickly carbonation. The flavor of figs, dried fruit, and burnt sugar is not as strong as the nose. Subtle leather, a touchof biscuit and toast, dry finish.

Conclusion. A classic dubbel. Not as good or as interesting as either a Chimay red or blue label, but a solid dubbel nonetheless.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 A Dubble trappist beer. Lots of different flavours.
Nice brow head, caramel aroma, dark fruits.

Deep brown in the glass with a thick tan head.  Aroma of brown sugar and dried fruits with a spicy yeast note.  Great malty profile on the palate.  Rich mouthfeel.  Just a touch of alcohol.  Great beer.
bottle. fluffy tan head, amber color. aroma of dark fruits. taste is crisp, a light sourness at first. fruit comes out as it warms. dry finish.

Dark brown head with a creamy light brown head. Looks beautiful in its chalice. Aroma is lightly fruity with hints of malt and chocolate. Taste is sweet and roasted with hints of fruit. Balanced magnificently with a light bitter finish. Glorious!

Birra notevole che dellequilibrio tra note maltate e luppolo un punto di forza. Color rubino, schiuma notevole e persistente al naso è  malto,  caramello e una punta di  luppolo. Al palato è ben strutturata con note più accentuate di luppolo e leggermente vinosa. Ottima!

33 mL bottle into a Westmalle glass.  Very dark beer with a hint of purple.  Looks the business.  Good but short lived head.  Very rich and strong tasting head, but subtley blended.  A very rich and strong trappist beer which hides its alcohol strength well.  Tastes special and always has, one of my favourite beers in the world.  Rich and full and with a few hidden features that require further tasting.  Excellcent.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2012 bel colore rubino scuro con notevole schiuma di medio-lunga durata.aroma vinoso e fruttato (banana prugna) e gia si sente il luppolo!!in bocca stuzzica una nota  piccante e una perfetta frizzantezza!poi pian piano si sente lalcool il mallto tostato lla frutta secca !al palato esce una sorprendente luppolaturra !grande birra!
bevuta dopo un anno in cantina e sono rimasto un po deluso.lho trovata piu piatta

head: foamy ,off white 
colour: deep red/brown 
smell: malts, yeast, bitter , a bit irony 
taste: start is malts and yeast , then comes some candy and or sweet taste, irony in the end and a bit dry ... not bad but there are better dubbel trappists ...

Pour into chalice glass, reddish brown, cloudy with sediment. Thought the aroma would burst out of this close to 2 year old bottle as the beer did, but no strong pleasant odor was noticed. To taste, I got plum, other dark fruits, red wine taste. Palate is a little thin, fruity all the way with a touch of sourness. Bad bottle? Poor storage? Kind of underwhelming.
18th February 2008  A 1970s bottle sourced from a collector in Belgium. Cloudy brown beer, still carbonated! Sharp and sour with a dry bitter finish. Nice but a bit too dry.

Bottle 330ml. Exceptional. Aromas of dough, caramel, and chocolate. Taste is subtle, sweet, with bitter notes, and long length. Palate is velvety, smooth, with a medium-to-full body. Dark brown, with a frothy head.
Great Trappist beer. It was once my first abbey ale and ever since I think this is the best Trappist. Should be drunk from the chalice glass.

Pours dark and cloudy with a good foamy head.
Has a fruity, caramel aroma with hints of roasted malt.
Tastes medium bitter with a light alcohol aftertaste.

BBE: 01/09/11 sampled 01/08/11 Very old spiderweb laced aroma. Overripe apple, kiwifruit,  and coconut notes also present. Opaque brown, huge tan head. nice lacing. Dry and woody rotten apple flavor, with definite spider web accents. Finish is apple skins and barley husks, bordering on cardboard. I wasnt expecting this to be one of the better trappist ales, but it was distinctly good. I especially loved the mustiness.

330 ml bottle in Germany. Let this one warm before you open it. Pours a very dark ruby brown color, with a very long lasting light brown head. Aroma is quite dry with a good fruity pear presence, some alcohol, malt even makes an appearance. Taste is malty with a very effervescent quality, a strong fruit content that follows with the pear aftertaste and also a good sweet caramel flavor. Fairly quick lightly sour finish, that makes you want to drink more the second it makes its way to your stomach. I paid .88 cents for it at a supermarket. It was 4 Euros at the Bier Temple. I have become a huge fan of this Brewery.
Pours cloudy dark brown, medium head that quickly dissipates, no lacing.  Taste of caramel malt, grows through a long warm alcohol finish.  Solid brew that drinks easy and lasts pleasantly.

Da una degustazione verticale di 5 annate differenti la birra matura ed evolve di anno in anno il suo corpo ed assume connotati sempre più complessi. Il colore va da rosso scuro fino al marrone più intenso.
La schiuma è densa e persistenze le sensazioni olfattve decise e marcate di ciollato con lievi sentori di affumicato. Al palato è complessa e ricca con un finale piacevolmente amaro di coriandolo. La versione in fusto distribuita in italia non merita cenno alcuno, il prodotto è standardizzato e piatto sotto ogni suo aspetto. Nel suo genere resta comunque un caposaldo della categoria.
Il colore è un bel marrone scuro-nero con cappello abbondante di schiuma beige. Laroma è abbastanza dolce, con tracce di cacao. In bocca è buona, niente da dire ma io me la ricordavo molto meglio.
Birra molto complessa ultimamente la trovo un po peggiorata ma resta sempre tra le mie preferite.

750 mL bottle at home. Red/brown appearance with a nice cream/brown head. Great sweet candy sugar with darkish Belgian ale nose. Great dark
malty body whe still retaining a dark candy sugar and Belgian ale flavor. Great beer.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 330 ml, BB date reads 12. November 2010, into 180 ml Chimay chalice. Up until today Ive been waiting to open this one to enjoy the benefits of maturation. Pours effervescent, deep reddish coppery body with good clarity, topped by medium, beige dense head with good retention that gradually sets to a stable cloth. Nice lacing on the walls.
The nose is low maltiness dominated by fruity esters of plum, apple and raisins, light phenolic spiciness and apparent perfumy qualities probably originating from higher alcohols. Occasionally some extra sweetness emerges enhancing the perception of malt. The flavor is surprisingly unsweet, lacking prominent malt perception, estery with fruity tartness of plum, apple and raisins, light bitterness with moderately dry finish and some yeastiness. Light to medium bodied with rather high carbonation. A year of cellaring hasnt taken away much of the tartness (without diminishing the fruitiness) as I hoped for and which was the case with some previously tasted bottles.

In short: a rather dry, tart and estery dubbel with attractive reddish depth.

UPDATE 12-28-2010:
This bottle has been aged a year over the declared best before date (18.December 2009).
A gusher, although once poured exhibits less effervescence than a year younger bottle tasted previous evening. Pour into baby-Chimay chalice (180 ml) gives birth to a deep amber-coppery clear body with some haze, overlain by beige head that completely dissipates in a short time. The aroma is rich and complex yet discrete malty sweetness with faint chocolaty notes, hint of caramel and light toastiness, abundant fruity esters of ripened plum and raisins, port-wine reminiscent qualities, some spicy phenolics and apparent higher alcohol-derived perfuminess. The flavor is complex malty sweetness with light toasty notes, plums & raisins lacking the prominent, almost berry-like tartness of a young Westmalle, light bitterness, some phenolic spiciness and yeasty notes. The malty sensation persists into the semi-dry finish. Nearly medium bodied with rather flat carbonation.
A year past its declared BB date, the Westmalle Dubbel is mainly distinguished from his above reviewed younger brother by more pronounced sweetness enhancing the malt-perception, absence of fruity tartness and poorly sustained head with less carbonated body. The scores for this one are 9, 3, 8, 2, 15 = 3,7

Bottle 0,33ltr: Strange that I have not reviewed this beer, after all those years of rating. For the first time a cooked with beer, which incidentally had succeeded wonderfully with this Dubbe. Hazy dark brown brew with an subtle bittersweet taste, and hints of caramel, an true classic.

Tumman ruskean ja punertavan sekoitus on tämän oluen väri. Valkoinen, hieman ruskeaan vivahtava vaahto on suhteellisen niukka. Vaahdon laskeuduttua jää oluen pinnalle erittäin ohut kerros tätä samaista tavaraa. Aromi on tumman hedelmäinen, rusinainen ja maltainen. Maussa on näiden lisäksi pieni vivahde alkoholiin ja mausteisuuskin piipahtaa suussa. Suutuntuma on mukavan runsas. Kyllä tämä minulle maistuu.

33cl bottle from Cask & Kitchen, Pimlico. Pours dark mahogany with bubbly beige head. Nose; Varnish, pear-drops, yeasty. Taste; dark fruits (figs, cherry and plums), varnish, wood, pear with a tart/astringent finish. Complex and enjoyable.

330ml bottle from Auchan Market, Luxembourg City!
The beer is dark reddish brown, the monstrous foam shows very fine and slightly creamy-colored. Smells sweet, malty, minimally sourish. The first sip is very malty, roasty minimal and pleasant hoppy-bitter. Later in the Dubbel is somewhat woody and bitter, does an almost smoky flavor to be, especially in the aftertaste! I am truly excited about this Trappist, which Ive certainly not drunk for the last time!
We probably had a bad bottle. This was a bit of a disappointment. Barely any taste. Whiskey and alcohol.
overwhelming aroma of whiskey and alcohol. the aroma overwhelms the taste as well. not really a pleasant experience. was my first trappist so i was quite disappointed

This is the first trappist ale to disappoint. Significantly different tasting then the others I have tasted. First you notice a very similar smell to whiskey and the flavour is quite similar to the smell as well. Glad I only purchased the one bottle because at the price it is over here, thats all I am likely to purchase.

33 cl flaske. Mørkebrun med en rød tone, stor off-white hovede. En meget rafineret og kompleks smag, som er svær at skelne neuanser.
Lys karemel er dog dominerende med jeg fornemmer også en snert af rosin. En fin og lidt tør afbalenceret finish. DK-B-69,00

nero impenetrabile, malto tostato scuro, calda di alcol, ma scorrevole. molto piacevole, va abbinata al cibo correttamente. bella esperienza.                   impenetrable black, dark roasted malt, hot alcohol, but smooth. very nice, it goes to the food properly. good experience.

06/12/2010 - 33cl bottle @ home
Dark brown slightly clouded beer, big beige creamy and adhesive head, very stable. A little sediment floating around. Aroma: banana, dried fruits, caramel. MF: nice carbon, full body. Taste: mocha, dark chocolate, sour fruits. Aftertaste: hop bitter, tart, banana.
Note: so I finally got around to taking some notes for the trappists. Ive been drinking them for years and usually when I did not felt like sampling something new and taking notes. Tasted them with 2 friends for a trappist review article in the student society magazine.
Not too much on the nose up front; beautiful looking brown with thick frothy head; taste is dry spicy with dark fruit accents; finish clean and dry

Bottle. Very dark brown, large mostly lasting light brown head. Moderate malty sweetish aroma, fruity with plums and dates, faint notes of spiciness. Body is average, malty and lightly sweetish aroma, some hoppyness with light spiciness. Finish is average, malty and dryish. Quite dry dubbel with nice hoppy aroma and flavor (and not too spicy).

Ruddy dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, spices, raisons and brown sugar.  Taste is standard dubbel faire dark fruits, yeast, candi sugar along with spices, malt and brown sugar.  Finish is spicy with just a hint of bitterness.  Decent.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2012 A very dark brown beer with a big and beige head. Aroma is full, plums, raisins, some redcurrants and syrup sweetness; overally aroma is full and fruitfull, pleasant. Almost full-bodied, smooth and nice to drink. Lot of dark fruits also in the flavour, plums and raisins, honey and syrup. Flavour is not very sweet, but balanced and quite dry and long aftertaste. High quality and pleasant dubbel, but the last unique nuancees are missing.

Appearance:  medium hazy brown; one-finger white head that shrinks but remains thick; tons of lace.  Aroma:  raisins, maple syrup, brown sugar, dark grains, hint of red wine.  Taste:  lightly toasted brown bread, unsweetened molasses, hint of brown sugar.  Finish:  tingly and crisp with an underlying mineral note.  Notes:  Very fine dubbel, but I much prefer the Chimay Red.  This one is a little too sharp on the palate, and I would have liked the flavors to be as sweet as the aroma indicated. Still very good.

Bottle.  Somehow, I think this is my first ever Westmalle dubbel.  Pours a dark, reddish brown with aromas of yeast, sweet fruits and malt.  The flavors consist of sweet malty yeastiness with dark, sweet fruit.  A good beer.

Pours a dark brown with a few reddish highlights. Off white head and good lacing. Smell is dark plums and raisins with a good amount of caramel and dark sugars. Taste is a bit less unrefined, with the yeast characteristics not coming through nearly as much. More of a bready-type flavor. Mouthfeel is fairly full and rich. Drinkability is okay; not nearly as impressive as their tripel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2010

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Dark brown, good foamy head. Toasty, nutty, basement aromas, leather. Delicate aroma. Good rich bitterness balanced with malty sweetness. Lots of flavour. Full tasty, great for a cold day. Dont drink too cold.
Flaskan är ursnygg med kransen på halsen. Innehållet är gott, med en del citrus, emellertid inte fullt lika mycket som t ex Orval eller Grimbergen Blonde, och på det stora hela ett gott belgiskt öl.

Bottle served in a champagne glass. Bottle brown in color with a very large billowing head. Aroma is sweet wild cherry ludens cough drops. Theres also fig, prunes, and head. Flavor is sweet and a bit sour. Medium body, creamy, sticky-sweet palate, and a dry, sour cherry finish. Really nice.
The look reminds bok beer. There is no smell. Malty, strong alcoholic taste. Not interesting at all.

11.2 oz bottle from Spirits Red Bank. Poured a slight murky deep dark mahogany with a large thick full foamy biege head that lasts and lasts. Aroma is sweet with notes of uncooked raisin bread, yeast, nuts, sugar, pureed raisin, dark fruit juice. Velvety mouthfeel with a full body and light carbonation. Flavors of yeast, sugar, prune, plum, dates, raisins, nutts, brown bread. This one is interesting and solid and seems more like a quad then a dubbel.

Small bottle. Reddish brown body, beautiful head with fine bubbles. Moderate yeasty aroma with dark fruits. Taste is dry and mellow with some caramel and pear. Finish has light chocolate. Very easy to drink.
Cloudy brown color, with less head than many Belgians. Description of malt and fruit is right on. Alcohol and hops didnt appear.

Hazy brown pour, lasting creamy tan head keeps going and going.  Aroma of raisin, prune, dark candy.  Taste = aroma X 2, mild sweetness countered by punch of bitterness.  Very fizzy on the tongue, a bit too much for my taste.  Much what was expected with more complexity (+) and extra lively carbonation(-).  Would definitely drink this again.  Interesting!

Aromas of dark fruit, esters, caramel, slight roasty-toasty, brown sugar. Dark red-brown, slight haze, tan-brown lasting head...good lacing. Medium+ sweetness and a touch of bitterness to keep things in check. Medium body and carbonation, cricky texture, nice long malty finish of aforementioned aromas. Solid.

Pours murky deep ruty red with tan head. The aroma is full of dark fruity esters, brown sugar and yeasty spiciness. It smells smooth and silky. The taste isnt nearly as smooth as the prickly carbonation tends to erupt across my palate delivering notes of brown sugar, sweet prunes, ripe cherries and over ripe peaches. Under the fruitiness is a pleasing level of caramel candy coupled to modest amounts of yeasty spiciness. Solid stuff.

Bottle.A: Reddish brown. In short:caramel, floral, raisin, plums, earthy, alcohol. Medium sweetness with a little bitter aftertaste. Gets better as it warms up, fuller body and more flavor. It´s ok, give it a chance why wont chaaa!!
Poured dark purple with off white head that lasted smelled sweet malty plums and raisons tasted the same with slight alcohol aftertaste

Reddish in colour featuring a rich beige head. The aroma is rich in esters, almost malty vanilla and butterscotch and then it enters into a fruity powerhouse. On the palate it is really rich, creamy, balanced and possesses a nice long finish. well carbonated and slightly bitter and very very pleasing taste this brew is one of my all time favs.

Sweety nose and deep brown colour. A slick texture and a very creamy white head for this delicious Trappist beer. Aromas of coffee, wood, caramel and roasted malts. Lively carbonation, light bitter and medium sweet. Tasty, spicy and strong beer, even if not the best Trappist.

malty, bready aroma, but not that strong or pleasing. Brown appearance with a big tall, rocky dark tan head. Could taste the malt with some fruity sweetness. Lively carbonation, medium body. Overall good but not great

11.2 oz bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a towering beige head. Subtle aroma of caramel malts, brown sugar and dry red wine. Flavour of caramel malts, fruity notes and that dry red wine-ish quality. Quite good, though below expectations.

Bouteille de 341ml (gracieuseté de slovaksniper, merci) Cette bière trappiste brune a une mousse beige foncée pas mal dense au sommet. Les épices se font sentir au premier nez, de plus on peut percevoir un peu de malt chocolat. En bouche la forte carbonation se fait sentir demblée, on détecte aussi des épices et un peu de cacao le tout dans un parfait équilibre. Une réussite.

Bottle:
Light brown to off white foamy head on top of a brown beer.
Smell some toasted/roasted malts, brown sugars, darker fruits like prunes.
Taste is a pretty fine mix of: sweet and sugary malty, fruits, hops, malts, hints of chocolate, bitter, grassy, spices and wheat.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 Nem vagyok barna sör fan ez tény, így nem túl sokat kóstoltam, még... 
Barna és ráadásul trapista létére elég gyengécske illat csapja? meg az orrunkat. Enyhe méz és banán buké érezhető de ezt gyorsan elnyomja az alkohol markáns ereje. Erősen komlós. 
Többet vártam na! Ízre is középszerű nekem nem elég sűrű, karcos barna létére. Ami viszont színpatikus az egyben rezgő, remegő sűrű habkorona ami idővel 2-3mm-es  gyöngyökből álló világos barna takaróvá változik.
 Vannak jobb trapisták!

Not much on the nose, maybe a little raisin. Dark Brown in color with a good retaining head. Starts off with a coffee flavor that turns very bitter before offering some Dark fruit notes. Just Okay. Expected more from this Ale

Dark brown beer w/ a light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt and bread.  Taste is slightly sweet with dark, dried fruit flavors - such as dried apricots or plums.  Finish is sweet with more fruit flavor.

33 cl bottle poured in a Westmalle glass. Pours brown with some red notes and a small brown head. Very fruity and sweet nose with some roasted malts as well. Taste is sweet (dark brown sugar) and a bit sour at the same time, however Id liked some more complex flavours. All in all very drinkable this one, but not the best trappist around.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2011 In bottle (Numerous times in Belgium); great beer. Aroma of coffee and caramel. Taste, very easy drinking. Notes of caramel and coffee. I really enjoyed this beer (more than I expected). I would highly recommend.

La robe est rouge brunâtre.  Le col de mousse foncé est épais.  Une dentelle reste accrochée à la surface du calice.  Au nez, belle présence de notes légèrement grillées et enrobées de caramel.  Les esters sont complexes avec des effluves délicats de banane et de raisin.  On note aussi une légère touche acidulée qui fait penser à la pomme.  La levure belge épicée et le parfum dalcool se définissent avec délicatesse et font oublier la très faible présence des houblons.  Au goût, pas très différent des arômes : le malt et la levure sont imposants, les épices sont présents mais timides, lalcool chatouille les papilles tandis que les saveurs de raisin tendent à se marier avec ce goût légèrement acide de pomme verte.  En bouche, le liquide est de moyenne corpulence avec une effervescence juste à point et une texture caressante.  Quelques notes douces et amères en arrière-goût.  En résumé, classique.

Pours brown with a foamy light brown head. Nose is typical dubbel with a lot of brown sugar and belgian yeast. Flavor is rich and immersed in caramel, brown sugar, abbey yeast, and just a touch of hops and spice. Backside is slightly sticky and quite sweet. This is a very good example of the style.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured hazy, with a ruby color and a massive, tan, quick to disappear lacing head. Very good presentation. Plum, yeast, brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon in the aroma. Somewhat earthy, with wood cask notes. Dense, oily body with medium carbonation. Long lasting roasty, fruity aftertaste. Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2011 330 ml bottle @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio. Rated @ 2.7.2009.
Dark brown colour with a small white head. Roasted malts, caramel, sweet fruits and yeast on the nose. Flavour of fruits and malts with decent roastiness. Full bodied and oily texture. One of the best Dubbels in my opinion. 9+4+9+4+17
750 ml bottle.
Pours a deep amber colour with a very large, beigeish head. Aroma of toasted malts, nuts and dried fruits. Flavour of toasted malts, dried fruits, orange peel, nuts and some bitter hops. Full bodied, slick mouthfeel and a fruity, malty and light bitter finish. Very nice Dubbel, but I have to drop the points a bit. Too malty.

Dark brown beer with big creamy head.Smell roasted  malts,tropic fruits,bitter chocolate.Taste roasted malts,chocolate,caramel,coffee,mentha.spices.Long lasting finish.Nice smoothy feeling all over the mouth.A very enjoyable beer.
Poured from bottle, dark orange/brown, some sediment, medium head, good lacing. Smooth, full, rich, yeast flavor. Nice body. Nice aroma. Goes well with my chiminea time on the back patio.

Pours a dense, milk-chocolate brown color with a thinner head than I expected for a Trappist. The dry, champagne sweet aroma doesnt seem to have much of the dark fruit character Id expect from the style and actually gives a hint of the moderate alcohol content. The taste is much truer to style, with flavors of raisins, sweet (rather than tart) cherries, and a caramel sweetness. The effervescence mutes some of the flavor while helping it slip over the tongue with a silky drinkability.

Aroma is astringent with puckery grapes and cherries: very sweet. Berries come in more than any dark fruits.

The appearance is cloudy red-orange, with lots of sediment. Light red wine. Head stays a couple minutes.

Belgian funk in the flavor, of course, with a sweet, puckery berry finish. Sweet grapes, sour cherry. Earthy, horsey base (mild). Pleasant, though a bit underwhelming. Much sweeter than expected.

Feels bubbly, if a tad fizzy. Finishes very dry, like sherry. Sandpapery. A little slick at the end. I know this is considered world-class, but to me, its just good ... not great. Could use a darker foundation.

Bottle @SportPub Chelsea, Helsinki. Poured cloudy, red/brown color with a nice beige head. Aroma is spices, yeast and fruits and malt. Flavor is caramel malt, dark fruit, yeast and spices. Quite highly carbonated. Slightly sweet finish. Overall a very enjoyable dubbel.
Bottle. Dark brown with a large beige head. Malts and some yeast in the aroma. Tastes of brown sugar, apple juice (or äppelmust). Quite thin and simple compared to some other dubbels.

Bottle - Pours murky mahogany with a huge foamy light tan head. Fruity aroma with hints of apricot, raspberry jam, raisin, and a sweet breadiness. Big and bready taste, with a bit of caramel sweetness up front and a dry, nutty finish. One of the best of the style that Ive had.

Bottle from Systembolaget. I keep returning to this. The tripple might have a little more taste, but I quite often prefer the lower alcohol level of the dubbel. A nice Come Home From Work beer for the Friday evening.

Bottle. Large off-white tan foamy head over a hazy red brown body. Aroma-taste of apple/pear juice concentrate, cloves,bitter chocolate finishing with a moderate mouthfilling bitterness. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Nice.
Really good. I think this may get over looked some compared to their tripel.  Dark loveliness. Serving: Bottle and tap
Not very much aroma but with a caramel with hop sent. Tastes better towards the end of the pint as the different tastes are not quickly released.

Rezes sötétbarna színű főzet, bézs habja krémes és vékonyan megmarad a tetején.
Illata gyümölcsös és fűszeres.
Picit csípősen kezd, íze aszalt gyümölcsöket idéz.
Enyhén fanyar aromája pörkölt, gabonás, citrusos hatásokat hordoz magával.
Befejezése fanyar, kesernyés, kicsit melengető és száraz.
Teste sima és a viszonylag magasabb alkohol tartalom alig-alig érezhető.
Összességében egy jófajta, élvezetes trappista dupla.

Aroma of raisins and nuts, with a little dark cherry and some herbal notes.  Has a huge, cream colored head that slowly dissipates and leaves lacing.  Color is dark brown with an orange-red tinge.  This is a very fruity beer, with the focus mainly on the malt and yeast.  It seems to have elements of all of the flavors, it starts off sweet, then tastes somewhat bitter and sour, and even has a little saltiness.  The flavors are very subtle and not overwhelming at all.  It is highly carbonated, with a full body and slick texture.  The finish is sweet, sour, and bitter all at once, and is quite long.  The alcohol is quite noticeable, this beer really packs a punch.  I think it lives up to the hype overall.  The high price makes it an occasional treat.

Bottle. Bitter. Should leave it a while to warm. Should be rating this on draught at Den Engel. Or maybe that 14 year old bottle from the Kulminator. Liquid plum pudding. Nice lacing down the side of the glass. Flavours starting to open up. Spicy, malty. raisins with a drying finish.

The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Deep black, nice head. Starts malty and strong, quite fruity like berries, more and more sourish. Finsih well balanced, malty-fruity, but also quite dry. The notes should be more intense, but still a good beer!

A: snifter. opaque mahogany color. nice light tan head. great retention and great lacing.

S: wonderful fruity aroma. some figs, pears, plums and some clove.

T: nice and mellow. flavors of fig, plum and clove mostly. great palate for a dubbel.

M: clean and crisp for the style. great carbonation level. medium to full bodied.

D: great dubbel...as with almost all trappist beers, give it a shot and you wont be disappointed.
Pour a nice brown with a brown head. Sweet aroma and flavor , but not too sweet. finishes nice and smooth. This beer makes me want to take a trip to Belgium.
Bottle pours a red/brown beer with almost no head. Fruit scent. Taste is sour and fruity. Bubbly. Refreshing.

I think this one went bad...I know that beer doesnt really have issues with refrigeration and then warming a couple times, but the power outages around here didnt help this one...Ive also had it for a year and I dont think thats a good thing.

Overly carbonated and a flat sweet fruit flavor that I didnt love.  Dried plum, some anice,  and a fairly flat finish.  I know its supposed to be great, Im gonna find another one...

330 ml bottle. Cloudy dark reddish brown colour, medium-sized light beige head. Aroma of sweet dark fruits, caramel malts, spices and brown sugar. The flavour is sweetish, bread-like, malty, with dark fruits and a spicy, warm finish.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2017 [8/10] Mahogany with a fat coat of beige head. Smells of stewed prunes, cheesy yeast, caramel, vanilla. Taste is sweet fruity with dough and spices. Quite light mouthfeel is rather too carbonated at first. Depth of malt and yeast emerges with a careful swirl or two in their distinctly unswirl-friendly glass. Some citrus sourness and mild spicy bitterness in a long dry finish. Good but not a knockout. [3.5] [3/17] I havent seen what others have in Westmalle yet. This is not the first revisit, but this time is a lot better (and Im guessing its just fresher): cleaner with prunes, dried banana, raisins, strong bread. Bitter with quite punchy spices in the dry finish.

Bottle 2008.  Aroma has notes of roasted malts, red wine, dark fruits and dark bread.  Sits almost black in the glass with an average sized off-white head that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is sweet and acidic.  Palate is medium bodied and watery soft.  Overall a decent Dubbel but the 2 years in the bottle didnt do it any favors.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2011 Im reviewing this from memory, so I cant give much details. Note on later date:I need to try this again, I had it when my palate was not developed enough.
Bottle from Systembolaget. Opaque dark brown beer and creamy off-white head with lace. Malty aroma has dried plumbs. Sourish and malty taste has rhum and fruity features and is quite complex.

330ml bottle, Trappist glass.  Looks handsome in the glass - deep chestnut brown-red hue with sediment lazily mingling amongst it, and a large fluffy fully lasting beige head topped with a sprinkling of dark brown sediment crowning it nicely and leaving a wonderful curtain of lacing.  The complex milieu of aromas and flavours are in unity - sweet brown sugar, toffee, ripe dark fruit especially raisin, almond/marzipan, spicy cinnamon, yeasty especially cheese, mild bitter chocolate, slight sour green apple  Although the Westmalle Tripel  was outstanding and noticeably better than this, the Dubbel is still absolutely delightful.

Served from bottle to a Westmalle chalice.

Appearance: brown cola color, cream head that stays for awhile, visible carbonation, leaving liquidy spiderweb lace.

Aroma:  raisins, licorice, brown sugar, little alcohol, cola, malts.

Taste: Alcohol, malts, brown sugar, raisins.

Palate: feels little watery, not much of a lingering flavor.

As personal preference, from trappist beers I like better Chimay for its spiciness, or Rochefort 10.

But then again its a good beer, for me in this kind its not the best and Im in the hunt for the Westvleteren so it might go down another notch in the trappist war if theres any.

pours a gorgeous clear ruby/amber with a huge fluffy light tan head, that leaves generous lacing as it patiently fades.  big delicious scent of malt, black cherries, plums, and raisins, some woody notes, and the slightest hint of spice.  the taste is slightly disappointing, with mostly a generic malt flavor, with some grassy hops.  i was hoping for more belgian esters, such as permeate the smell.  good bubbly mouthfeel, a dry and lightly bitter finish, good bit of body to it.  maybe my expectations were too high, but i strongly preferred the tripel.

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours dark brown with a little red mixed in there, the head is outstanding, two fingers thick, the foam has a reddish tint to it. The aroma is somewhat subdued, yeast, raisins and some spice. The flavor is yeasty and thick, a very good dubbel, but not in line to be the best. Nice how the head lasts even in my big wide mouth Chimay glass, beautiful beer.

33cl bottle. Colour is conform type. A little banana aroma but the yeast is much more eminent. Also a  hint of malt easily tops the banana. Dark malty taste, smooth mouthfeel, bit sweet. Not the heavy cloves taste from Leffe.

A: The pour is a dark amber color with a big tan colored head.

S: The nose is good, but not amazing. Some dark fruits in the form of raisins, plums, and figs with plenty of sweet malt notes: molasses, caramel, and toffee.

T: A lot more intensity to the flavor. A great malt character thats bready with excellent but balanced sweetness that provides some molasses, toffee, caramel. The fruits are over-ripe and sweet, mostly cherries, plums, and figs.

M: Medium in body with very ample carbonation, as you would expect for a Belgian ale.

D: Really a delicious and easy to drink beer. One of the better dubbels Ive had in awhile.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a deep, murky reddish brown with a nice beige head. Aroma has notes of dark fruit, spice, light dark roast, musty, light signs of bread. Flavor of light malt, yeasty, light dark fruit, some dark toasted grain, spicy, notes of burnt caramel, musty, some farmhouse notes and a little bit of earth. Mouth feel is medium body with very lively carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable beer!
Dark red pour from bottle.  Pillowy 3 finger head.  Nose and taste is dried fruits and pie spices.  Very smooth finish, especially compared to higher abv Belgian Ales.  Very good.

Bottle. Poured a dark murky brown with a tan fizzy head that was fully diminishing and had poor lacing. The aroma was heavy of roasted malts and molasses, light resin hops and a moderate scent of a horse blanket yeast. It tasted slightly malty and extremely bitter at first and ended with a bitter acidic flavor that layed in the back of your throat. Mouthfeel was light in body and watery in texture with a fizzy carbonation. Overall an OK brew, but nothing special.

Nice aroma of bread and caramel. Quickly disappearing brown head. Taste is nice... .medium sweetness, with normal caramel flavors. Not the best of the trappist beers, but compared to all beers a good choice.
Poured with a little too much head perhaps, but redeemed itself with a full smoky flavor that kicks you in the teeth. Exceptionally smooth finish. The monks continue to make outstanding beer.

330mL bottle.  Pours hazy dark red with a large fluffy head that settles to a persistent covering.  Aromas of banana, apple, spice, dark fruit and yeast.  Subdued flavours, low bitterness, mild sweetness, some toasty and biscuity flavours and a slight acidity.  Medium bodied, lively carbonation and a slightly starchy dry finish.

I really liked this one. Pours brown- blood red with light brown head. Its aroma and taste are simply unique. Full malty taste with other spices and bitter end. Really enjoyable when you need to drink a dubbel and perhaps the best choice for me.

Bottle poured in Westmalle glass. Pours a very dark brown beer with a nice tanned head. Westmalle Dubbel is bottle conditioned so there is a lot of carbonation going on. My example had a distinct aroma of apples, it kind of surprised me since this is something I normally associate with Geuze Lambics. Taste is again apples at first and then the sweet, smooth taste of malt and raisins perhaps (?). Aftertaste lasts quite a while. Westmalle Dubbel is one of the best examples of a strong dark trappist ale. Just like their Tripel, the Dubbel is another winner from Westmalle. Highly recommended.

750ml shared with DarkBeerChick.  Pours a deep, cola-colored body with a bubbly, tan head that leaves some good lacing.  Aromas of candi sugars, Belgian yeast, dates, candied figs, raisin bread and some spicyness.  Flavors of dark dried fruits, yeasty, some alcohol, bready and a bit of bakers cocoa.  Active, soft carbonation and a medium to full mouthfeel.

Aroma is sweet with raisins and molasses. Color is deep amber with some haziness.  Slightly sweet with a slight bitter finish. Taste is a bit fruity with some nutty caramel. Lots of carbonation.  Great dubbel!

Served from a bottle at OTM Tasting Room. The appearance is a bubbling brown with a small head. The flavors are aromas are bready, grainy, touches of chocolate, and nutshell. The carbonation is high, a touch too high for my licking.

not sure if i am only trying the best beers but this is the fifth beer that i tried that is nearly perfect. after opening the bottle you are greeted by a surprisingly complex flavour for a dubbel. second only to rochefort 6. try it. you will like it.

Bottle from grocery store in Schipol airport. Poured darkish brown with billowy head. Too billowy in my opinion. Ale is heavy, malty, some spiciness. Doughy belgian yeast is clearly evident. Im not overly fond of dubbles, otherwise Id probably rate this higher.
Birra dal colore bruno rossastro con una schiuma abbondante e cremosa di colore nocciola.Allaroma evidenzia aromi fruttati (prugna) e di malto tostato.Al gusto vengono fuori i frutti e lalcol

Bottle from LCBO. Tastes of honey. The color is a darkish brown. There is not really as strong a finish to this beer as I thought there would be, but there doesnt need to be because this beer is reasonably thick. It is not as thick as I would like it to be, but it does the job. I am not happy about the head. It wasnt tight and stable. It kept growing on me making it difficult to drink the beer. The aftertaste that I am getting is a sweet flavour.
caramel, nuts, roasty, resin, leaves, leather, alcohol, raisin, licorice, woody,

Bottle poured into an oversized wine glass release some pleasant aromas, mainly raisin.  Color is dark brown.  As far as taste, the alcohol is not hidden well, though its not completely overpowering.  Theres a lively fizziness on the tounge.

All in all, I expected more complexity from this beer and am a tad bit disappointed.  I ended up pouring a good bit of it out, something I rarely do.

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. Looking at the previous ratings, I wonder if Ive drunk the same beer? Pours like cola, both appearance wise and the effervesence that comes with it. The aroma is negligible, with nothing standing out. Some cherry flavour, with a cough mixture taste in the finish, and a trace of banana which lingers well in the mouth. For 7%, it lacks body and becomes syrupy. It has the alcoholic taste, but not the pleasing, warming sensation I had hoped for, a yeasty aroma develops towards the end. Quite disappointing.

1 year old 33cl bottle
The appearance is darkbrown with a red shine and a creamy beige to yellowish head. Very appetizing appearance!
The nose has lots of malts and fruity esters, especially ripe banana and a slight touch of anise. The taste is giganticly smooth and starts with gentle roasted malts and ripe banana and proceeds to a robust coffee flavor. It ends in a slightly bitter fruit finish with some coffee touches.
A magnificent smooth drinking beer with great balanced flavors! Cant wait to taste the draught version!

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 tasted at the mondiale de la bière in Montréal. pours a deep brown with a long lasting brown head. aroma is sweet, dark fruits mainly plum, alcohol, and a bit vinous. taste is complex. sweet, malty, lots of caramel, and finishes with a bread type flavour. an unbelievable beer.

Bottle.

A - Dark, slightly cloudy, ruby color with a good sized foamy toasted marshmallow colored head. Average retention and a thin layer of patchy lacing left.

S - A lot of dried dark cherry and raisin along with some other dark fruit. Some juicy apple and a bit of citrus. Good amount of caramel and dark malt aroma. Pretty sweet with a slight fruity tartness, particularly from the dark cherry.

T - Starts with some dark and a bit of a bready taste of malt. Hints of caramel and very slight chocolate flavor. Some dark fruit comes out on top of this with plum and raisin being strongest. Some raisin and citrus accompanies these and some spice, cinnamon and nutmeg being the strongest. A slightly sweet and tart and juicy finish.

M - Medium body with just a bit more than average carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy.

D - Very drinkable, with a variety of flavors that are well balanced. Juicy and pretty refreshing, and I would gladly have another.

Notes: Best before 23/09/11. A very solid beer and good example of the style. Quite a bit of dark fruit, with a nice dark malt base. Very drinkable and an enjoyable flavor, but it just didnt really blow me away or really distinguish itself as a world class beer. It is certainly worth getting and a very good beer though, and I would happily drink it again.

Bottle 33cl. Brown ale with nice head that remains properly. Smell is on spices and smoked malt. Aroma is deep and sweet, nice creamy chocolate flavor, dry finish with a very good bitterness that remains long time. Notes of candy sugar. Very nice beer and not too alcoholic, typical belgian yeast aroma, this beer is like a dessert. Lovely

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Had this beer several times before with the same results.
Pours dark with a long lasting beige head. alcohol is wel masked. complex aroma . Good beer.

330 mL bottle, expiry 3-02-11, from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a branded Trappist glass. Pours murky mahogany with 1 cm of rocky tan head. Head quickly reduces to a thin cover and leaves very little lace. On the nose, aromas are primarily caramel, brown sugar and roasted malts, with figs and a hint of doughy yeast. On the tongue, flavour is moderately sweet up front, becoming even sweeter as it proceeds. Finish is long, lingering sweet malt. On the palate, medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent dubbel. Malts impart a delightfully complex sweetness. Among the very best dubbels out there. 2010-05-28

Bottle from Sams.  Pours very dark amber brown with inch-thick fluffy off-white head.  Nose of dark fruits (prunes and figs), some burnt sugar (caramel) and other sweet malt notes.  Taste is subtle at first, almost seeming thin... but its more that this beer takes its time with you, getting better as it warms.  None of the metallic notes that sometimes come through in dubbels.  Lovely light and lively palate.

Ooooh, just love this beer. Deep dark brown color with looong lasting large tanned head leaving great lacing on the glass. Complex aroma with raisins, fruits, spices and malts in aroma. Flavor is spicy, crisp, a bit sweet and malty, mmm. Full bodied and round on palate. Finishes a bit seet and hoppy. Enjoyable indeed.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 Bottle pours dark brown with large frothy off-white persistent head.  Aroma dark fruits, malts and Belgian yeast.  Taste dark fruits, spices, malts, yeast with minimally bitter finish.  palate a bit thin.  OK dubbel but it doesnt put it all together.
Pours dark brown mahagony with a huge male. Medium bodied and fizzy, lively carbonated palate

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 Bottle 1993 and a earlier tasting of a bottle from 1982, kindly shared by Nnudd. 
What a treat. 
Pouring it made a small tan/yellow head that disappeared immediately, leaving a nice mahogany body. 
The aroma was quite dim, dominated by nuts, dark fruits and caramel. 
Tasting it was very interesting and what a nice flavour, so smooth and balanced with notes of nuts, dark fruit, wood and port. 
Unfortunately it was pretty thin bodied which ruined the overall impression a little bit, nonetheless it was still a fantastic beer.

Sampled at Vineyards in Ottawa (in 2004). Had a best before date on the bottle, 05/05/06. This trappist brew poured a dark amber-red colour with a nice creamy head that stayed a while. The alcohol was very noticable in the scent. I could also smell hints of pears and apples. The taste began with the strong alcohol and finished on the fruits mentioned above. Overall, pretty light in all departments for a trappist beer.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown with a biege head that seems to last. Aroma of sweet fruit, caramel and malt.  Taste is very smooth and very complex.  Malty and fruity.  Not too sweet.  Hides the alcohol very well.  Outstanding.

Dark Brown Body and thick head  There are figgs; spices and dark chocolate on the nose., nutty texture, spices, fruits and chocolate on with a slightly oak finish.  Average carbonation. Really nice beer.

Im very disappointed about this beer. I expected a lot more from this. Well starting: nice appereance, deep red-brown color, fizzy beige head. But after this, as i taste it, the fizzy carbonation and alcohol dominates everything. I can hardly feel some maltyness. Very unbalanced. Some unpleasent bitterness. I have to give time this to settle down. In the aroma, some spicy fruityness unfolds, then some dry prunes. It doesnt work well at palate: the alcohol bite strong. PUNGENT.

33cL bottle, Trappist Tasting at Joe T.s. Pours a murky, dark cola-brown color; medium-bubbled, light-tan head with decent retention and solid lacing.
