Powerful aroma, raisin, sugar, plum, chocolate, beautiful cloudy purplish brown, flavor of sweet malt, grape, raisin, plum, something different ... unique flavor, of an odd initial aromatic bitterness. Finished sweet. Very enjoyable and unique.

Rating #150 

This trappist lies somewhere between a Chimay Red and Ommegang, being slightly less enjoyable than either.  The aroma was quite bold: fig, raisin, apple.  Flavor was a little to burnt for my liking, but still had the great caramel maltiness.  Felt a little of the burn on the tongue.

This will certainly not be the last time I drink this beer no matter how terrible it might be Ive got a source on this one for $2.75 per bottle.. HaHaHaHaHa!!! 

Rating # 495
Pours a deep dark mahogany body, and an insanely thick and rocky tan head. The aroma is rather cola like.. Chocolaty, with raisins, and dates, yeasty, and notes of old damp oak. Nice roasty flavor! Long suggestions of brown sugar, Toffee malts, pumpernickel bread, almonds, black pepper, and candied yams baked with brown sugar and charred marshmallows. Noting some suggestions of ripened summer Cherries dipped in chocolate fondue. Plenty of pepper and yeast in the finish very velvety lush mouth-feel. 
 A very nice Double, Ill age a few.. and, well,  at $2.75 a bottle.. this could become regular drinking around here! Divine, I tell you!

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2004 A beautiful beer with cream-white head and a dark golden body. A spicy and smoked taste with hints of malt and coffee, with a bitter aftertaste. It has a good and sharp mouthfeel, and is overall a good beer.
Dark brown color with beige head. Chocolat, caramel, coffee little bit spicy taste.

Goodo cho0colatey brown color with a whopping large head.  Aroma is a strong of wheat but has a good smell of grapes hiding behind it.  The flavor is a very full bodied dubbel.  A good oily palate really balances this beer out well and makes it very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2004 Bottle dated 19/08/05.  Beer pours (in Westmalle glass) a dark brown-red liquid with an enormous amount of cotton-soft topped off-white head that dissipates somewhat, but lingers and looks great.  Aroma is of brown sugar, dark plum, raisins, sweet fruit, port, chocolate.  Flavor is of plum, raisin, port, only vaguely sweet but brown sugar, chocolate, with a faint, but noticable hop taste which slightly mars this excellent product.  Otherwise, the ending is smooth and clean.  Also has a wonderful mouthfeel.  Sampled at 78 degrees Fahrenheit.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2005 Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice amount of off-white head. The head stays forever and the beer is excellently carbonated. Aroma is filled with spice. Taste has a great spice to it that starts kind of sweet and goes down very smooth. I think i got hints of apple in the taste too. Very good trappist.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2004 Rating #2 Bottle.  A ruby brown color with a laced tan head.  The aroma has roasted malts and banana.  Alcohol, caramel and dry malt flavors.  Rating #1 (7 3 7 4 16) Bottle @ Toronado.  A ruby brown color.  Ginger, brandy, dark malts, and wood.  A smooth, rich full bodied beer.
Reddish brown color with a  creamy beige head and lote of sediment. Lightly friuty and spicy aroma. Nice grape, malt, nutmeg and pepper flavors. Tons of carbonation.

Dark and deep red color.  Clinging white head.  Some fruit in the nose, not too much spice.  Warming taste, plenty of esters. This beer, like some have already said, is waaay too carbonated.  That lower its score from me a lot.

11 oz. (?) bottle. A lot of rich dark malt and caramel nuttiness softened by an oatmeal stout-like texture. Too carbonated, negatively affecting the palate. Most of the fruitiness I noted was in the aroma -- apple, pear and plum. Would love to see what this does in a 330 ml bottle with 2+ years of aging.
Muy buena cerveza (como buena cerveza de abadia) Ligero sabor afrutado. Es un poco cara.

This pours with a significant , creamy, perennial head; raison, chocolate, and banana nose; it has a sweet, cocoabutter, nutty (walnut?) flavor that's a slightly tart in the finish; nice balance. Not overly complex; though I really like  dubbels, this is one of the few that gives you alot without giving over-the-top, imposing funkiness that many others do. Drink mass quantities! Too bad it's so expensive, it'll be along time before I get another, myself.

Dark sludgy brown with rusty, tawny reddish edges, great cap of fluffy firm tan foam ever so tall and present, creepingly settling to an ever present murky skim and finely stitched lace sticks. Aroma is intially soft and ripe of fruits giving a blend of mango, grapes, passion, and pear skins. A nice earthy dusting of dry yeast and bread crusts settles across the top after a bit with ever so present gleams of candied sugars. Taste is plump and a bit overcarbonated which gets in the way for me with every sip, as soon as I begin to get something out of it taste wise, the carbonation wipes it away far to quickly. A bit too sharp for my tastes. Perhaps an aged bottle of a year or more would help as this was bottled 2004. What is there for tastes are some dullish fruity malts in a darker realm of plum, raisin, and dry figs, mixing a bit inbetween some pear and cherry pieces. Slight cocoa and a firm earthy yeasty dryness with just a pinch of spice and walnut skin dryness finish it out. Very nice finish. Body is full with a bit much on the carbonation scale which has a scratchy/chalky-like coat on the way down which sorta blends into the complex drying qualities in the finish after awhile, which I actually liked, so that made up for some of my dissatisfaction in the carbonation dept.. Overall, this is one to come back too, with age, I think this might round or smooth out and be one fun and fine ale to behold.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2005 Deep, dark murky color. The head was huge and slightly off-white. Aroma has peaches, cinnamon, bubblegum, alcohol and a little yeast.  Decent lacing. The alcohol is present in the flavor with some apple and lemon tartness. A little saltiness came through. Finishes with pepper and some deep port wine. I didnt notice the sweetness that others had.

Burgundy body topped by a beautiful mountainous light tan head that poseses tremendous staying power. The aroma is sweet bubble gum with some yeasty notes. Very well balanced sweetness.  The bubblegum flavor comes back just before the dry hoppy finish. A very nice beer.

Pours a huge light brown, five finger-head leaving just traces of lace, pour slowly.  Deep ruby color.  Good carbonation.  Medium bodied.  Starts malty and sweet, finishes with a good mix of hops and malt but a slightly hoppy aftertaste.  My 100th Belgian and not a bad one in the bunch.  $5.39 for a 330ml bottle.

Pours a nices reddish brown with an off white head. THe aroma is of fuit maybe raisins. THe taste is a little less fuirty than the smell might indicate. excellent stiff trappist taste with nice warming effect. Great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2007 Dark hazy brown color with a frothy light beige head and some cinnamon like sprinkles of sediment. Nose is hints of green apple and caramel. Flavor starts peppery with hints of cherry and some yeast with a long dry spicy hop finish.
Chestnut color, hazy, large tan head. Sweet malt, quite soft but assertive in its delivery, raisins, and some yeast. Soft, rich palate. Very well made dubbel in all respects.

Pours deep, ruddy red-brown with a large tan head (including some dark brown sediment).  Cherries, raisin, toast, spice, and a touch of banana in the aroma.  Flavor is fairly dry with vinous character, caramel, and touches of cherry around the edges.  High level of carbonation gives this beer a zesty mouthfeel.  Finishes with alcohol and bitterness.  A good beer but not distinctive.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2004 Bottled
Dark brown. Big creamy brown head. Aroma is fruity, a bit sweet, same time malty and alcoholic. Medium-bodied, carbonated, malty. Bitter aftertaste. (7/5/8/4/15)
Re-rate bottled BB 10/2004: Parfumic and complex aroma, smooth carbonated palate. (9/4/8/4/17)

Huge rocky, pillowy head. Yum. Heavy malt and fruity on taste and aroma. Bananas and raisins. Hint of alcohol. Zesty on the tongue - spicy with lively carbonation. Hops emerge towards the finish and then slowly fade away leaving a nice trace of aftertaste. Wonderful!
Poured a nice dark brown with a nice long lasting beige head.  Nice malty aroma. Medium bodied with a nice mixture of caramel malt and dark fruits. A very pleasant beer.
Pours brown with a light reddish hue around the edges. Thin tan head. Aroma is mildly sweet. Full and shewy mouthfeel. Bread, dark fruit, caramel, and spices. Mild bitter finish. A great dubbel.

Borwn in color,medium sized tan head that lasted for a nice long time and faded to a nice lace.Nice fruity aroma with hints of bread,yeast,malt and what seems almost a tea like character but then i could be dreaming.Very nice flavor up front fruity and sweet with a quick change to mild bitter in the middle and finishing up with a fruit bitterness.The alcohol is noticeable but not to overly so.IMO a very nice brew and well worth trying again.Thanks go to Nexxus for sending this fine brew my way.
Brown body with yeasty haze, beige head, obviously bottle-conditioned, esters in the nose. Malty, bready, medium sweetness, fruits, bubblegum, light hops.
Bottle - beautiful color!  Deep auburn/reddish body and tightly bubbled tan head.  Big, malt and lingering fruit flavor.  Lace foloowed nearly all the way down the glass.  Very nice!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 bottled: pours nice hazy mahogany with a tan rocky head that eventually disipated.  nice earth fruit aromas.  first drink was more of a fruit flavor to me, bananas and some spices, as the beer warmed a bit i got more of a toasted malted crunch coming out...quite complex and very good.  havent tried the rest of the westmalles but im going to the store, cuzz theyre damn good, if i must say so myself!

This Dubbel poured a clear brown body with a huge off white head that was very creamy and long lasting with excellent Belgian Lace on the glass. The aroma is lightly malty with alcohol and a breadiness in the background. Slightly sweet with a short, acidic finish. A good Dubbel, but I couldn't rate it any higher than this.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2008 Bottle  Poured a red/brown quite opaque brew with a huge head with standard retention. Great carbonation with strong body. Aroma is very spicy with no alcohol noticeable. Taste is great with the usual Belgian style mix of malts and hops with some added roastiness to that one. The spice mix is a bit stronger then expected but overall very enjoyable. Overall, this is a good beer but I was expecting something greater from this well known Trappist.
Re-rate 2008: Creamy texture, no alcohol, bubblegum-like taste. Very well balance from a very fresh bottle. Wow
Very opaque dark-red color. Pours a nice head that doesn't vanish fast. Rich Malt taste. There is a glimpse of chocolate, and an unusual but subtle bit of burned/roasted taste. Overall a good Dubbel.

Bottle pours a beautiful dark ruby black with a perfect head and very good lace.  The aroma is slightly yeasty and roasty, perhaps somewhat lacking.  The flavor is sweet, roasted, chocolate, somewhat hop like, and just very well balanced.  It seems better as it warms.  Perhaps more complex Ale fruit notes show through and seems a bit yeastier.  The palate is medium rich and slightly more carbonated than I expected.  Overall, not a bad Dubbel.

This beer pours a dark brown color with a nice fluffy head and leaves some lacing on the sides of the glass.  The aroma was yeasty with fruits and caramel.  The flavor was quite sweet and filled with caramel tones.  I had higher expectations for this.  It's a great beer, but it can't hold ground against others in the same category.
Dirty brown with light head. Aroma of alcohol, fruit and molases. Thin body. Effervescent. Malty and dry. Foamy in the mouth with dry bitter chocolate and a light fruit finish.

Pours a medium to light brown with a big thick head. Aromas include some dark fruits, malt and a mild spiciness. The carbonation is crisp. Breadlike yeasts, malt, some hops and quite dry in the finish. Overall the brew is good. Damn good

This beer was sampled at the 12 Hour Belgian Beer Festival 2004 in San Diego. This beer poured a murky brown color with a mild tannish and pearlish colored head. There was also a significant amount of yeasty deposits at the bottom of the glass. The nose is very fruity and yeasty with hints of lemon and a good helping of maltiness. The taste has some definite roasty qualities and some dark currant qualities..perhaps plums... definitely a dry alcoholic finish..a slight bit disappointing given its only a seven percenter. Overall this was very pleasant and enjoyable. Mild carbonation level.

Gigantic tan head of small bubbles.  Reduces to a nice cratered foam.  Good carbonation.  Slightly smokey, fruity aroma with cherries and raisins.  Beautiful dark brown/mahagony.  Excellent beer to look at.  Slightly sweet flavor with plenty of malt, roasted grains and a note of alcohol.  Nice warming as it goes down way to easy.  Dry and clean finish.  A top quality dubbel!
Large light brown head, rocky, good retention. and lace. Murky brown color. Earthy, yeasty nose. Medium body. Light malt flavors, yeast, fruits and caramel notes. Finish is fairly dry and fruity.

The pour produces a noisy, three-finger rocky tan head atop a murky mahogany body; holding it up to direct sunlight reveals a shocking magenta color. As the head subsides, spicy and metallic aromas give way to soft fruit- melon, pear, banana- accented by yeast and brown sugar, clove and bubblegum, and dark breadcrust. A spectre of latex paint (fusel alcohols?) emerges as the beer warms. Chewy granola flavors mingle with dried banana chips, vanilla, and an almost licorice stewed fruit/dark malt character- Good'n'Plenty candy? Light sweetness is tempered by the fluffy carbonation. Aftertaste reminds me of banana-and-chocolate-chip muffins, spiked with cheap white rum that I remember from college.
Mild Apple/pear aroma... Round medium body.... smooth slightly complex taste taste... Great Finish

While I still think Allagash dubbel is easier to drink, I think that this one is much more complex.  Nice cloudy ruby red almos tbrown look with very tiny bubbles and moderate head.  Lacing is moderate.  Moderatly sweet, yet it has a yeasty profile which balances it out.  Very slight hop balance.  Not bad, but for 7% I would think it would be more mellow than this.  Very nice to drink every once in a while.

Bottle. Ok, *expensive* bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown, large off-white head. Fruity, yeasty and alcohol in the nose. Lots of dark sweet fruit, thick candy malts and a balanced dose of spices and bitterness. Very nice. Not a style I normally seek out because some examples go overboard with spices, but this one is tamed down enough and smooth in that respect. I will say that the alcohol presence is not hidden that well, in fact my gut feel is that this is higher than the advertised 7%.

Bottle. A huge sized head that was ivory in hue, foamy and fine-medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting. The hue of this beer was reddish brown with a malty, sweet and fruity nose. The flavor was sweet, caramel and alcohol tasting with a smooth mouthfeel. This beer had good lacing to it. A worthwhile Abbey Dubbel and very recommended.

This bottle brew poured an extremely large head of foamy finely sized very long lasting light brown colored bubbles that left behind a very good lacing.  The wonderful aroma can be smelled from a distance of over 2 feet.  It has notes of mild caramel malts brown malts some vinuousness and mild spices.  The mouth feel is vinuois initially smooth and has an alcohol bite followed by a brown beer lingering taste.  Very potent tasting.  The flavor is a bit overpowered by the vinuousness of the alcoholic mouth feel.  Notes of caramel dark malt roasted malts and port come to mind.  A very interesting beer.  A must try.

Again, a possibly good beer wasted on someone who just isn't fond of the style.  It looked good pouring, deep chestnut brown with an ample tan head.  The aroma was raisins, currents, malt.  The flavor disappointed.  Slightly medicinal.

Dense, reddish brown with a large sandy head that quickly subsides. Savory, oaky and fruity aromas dominate. Very definate grape flavors, as well as some vegatable flaovrs, too - asparagas, maybe? Nice crisp, dry hops throughout the body. Finishes kinda weak, but still a nice brew.
Bottle w/exp 19/08/05.  Clear copper beer with no head and no lace.  And next to no aroma.  Mild flavor, and very drinkable.
Dark brown color with hints of red and a thick tan head. Aromas of malt, toffee and dried fruits. Fruit, nut and malt flavors. How about a Trappist cereal? Smooth body and crisp finish.
Bottle conditioned. Richly malty aromas with alcohol raisins and faint roast aromas. Balanced and very drinkable. Rich and tasty but lacking depth.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2004 Yeast, burnt malt, caramel, treacle toffee, raisins, candy, citrus - it's all in here, and very well put together too. However, try as I might, I just can't help but find these abbey dubbels a bit cloying. The first couple of sips are wonderful but, by the time I get to the end, it's all just too sickly to really rave about.

This chocolate brown beer has a rich, foamy, light brown head with nice lacing. Soft fruits waft from the glass, surrounded by light caramel and toasted grains. The medium-bodied palate is creamy with light herbaceous hops and dried figs. The finish is silky with a touch of unsweetened chocolate and oak.
Nice burgundy color with an off-white head. Prunes, grapes, and other spices dominate the aroma. Nice taste. Smooth. Dry fruits, spices in the taste. Very well balanced. Nice Dubbel.

pours breown with copper highlights fluffy head that fades to a thick lace. aromas of nuts, sweet malt, plums, figs cookie dough, yeast, faint orange. moderate body starting sweet with caromel and fruitness light cherry flavor, syrup balnced by orangy hops. orange lingers and slowly fades. hints at syrupy sweetness but well balanced with a fruity hop making a fruity beer to sit and think about.

Coca-Cola appearance. Huge pillow, lacey head. Yeast and alcohol nose. Bitter burnt sugar, alcohol warmth. Slight coffee, caramel, and herbs. Very smooth and deep. I enjoyed this one more than the tripel.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2004 Amber reddish body with a foamy tan head.  Aroma is strong and sweet fruity and malty with obvious berries notes. Very delicious! Flavor is nice but not too heavy. Sweet berries and fruit with a little alcohol underneath.
Tried a bottle of this my first time last nite.  Nicely deep brown with a giganta bubbly tan head. Complexity of dark fermented fruits, leather and some pepery notes.  Creamy smooth.  Really good.
Wow, dark brown with an absolutely huge light tan head. Malty and fruity nose, tastes like a Chimay Red crossed with a Rochefort...definite tobacco notes in the flavor.

Opaque brown with cream head. Malt and slight vinuous aroma. Light flavour of malt and dark fruit. A bit thin. Perhaps the high carbonation didn't allow the flavours to develop. Expected more. Thanks Mal3.
1/11/04:  bottle. brown body with no lacing.  aromas of fruit (raisin), malt and alcohol.  black cherry flavor with hints of tea and sweetness.
Dark brown/amber with a huge tan head. Sweet fruity/nutty aroma. Flavor of malt(bread)and  a little dark fruit. Dry and hoppy finish.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2011 Looks like a dream in the glass (used an Orval glass).  However no lace.  Tastes clean and dark-fruity with hints of banana.  Should be interested in tasting an aged bottle.  Score 4.0Subsequent rating scored 3.5. Average becomes 3.8

1996 vintage bottle. Tasted this beer with Maibockaddict. Reddish orange in color, with lots of floaties. Sharp, fruity aroma. Full bodied beer. Well aged bottle, and it was wonderful.

 Maibockaddict and I also had a newer version of this beer, a 2003 version.  More fresh aroma. Raisiny flavor, not as aged as the first one 8 years. It ages very well and its worth the  money.

1996 vintage (with a new 2003 vintage to follow)Part 3 of my Trappist tasting with Mkobes. pours a beautiful reddish orange with lots of floaties. Awesome head as with any trappist. Sharp fruity tobacco aroma. Yum. Full bodied musty tart malty flavor with fruity undertones. Obviously well aged, yet still wonderful. New version rated to follow in bold.  Newer version (2003?). # 4 in my trappist tasting with Mkobes. Pours deep orange red, with a few fewer floaties. Perfect Trappist head again. More fresh earth aroma than the 8n year old version. Some raisiny fruitiness, with a musty, tobacco undertone. Fruity raisiny flavor, with tobacco undertones, that is nice, yet not as aged, obviously, as the first. This ages well and is well worth paying hundreds of dollars a case. Nuff said
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
Bottle, doubtless old.
Nice leather color.  Pours cloudy with a nice cream head that stays for a time--well-structured.
Complex malty nose with aspects of currant, raisin, yeast.
Smooth, malty taste with depth.  Decent balance of malt and hop with dark berry, caramel hints.  Very nice.

2003? bottle. Burgundy red with deeper chestnut browns, fizzy (as expected) but a big off-white head with some brown flecks in it. bottle conditioned.  Aroma of bittersweet prunes, light phenols, dry gingerbread?, and a touch of sweet molasses.  Hmm, this is very light, much more so than expected or hoped for.  Good cinnamon, brown sugar, earthiness, rhubarb, dry raspberry and a touch of lightly sweet chocolate.  Very watery consistency, finish has some alcohol on it and a touch of astringency.  Not terribly impressed, will try again at some point.
Beautiful dark brown and think rich caramel head.  As for taste, compared to the other trappist beers with its nice spicy slightly fruity palate.  Well balanced alcohol, roast malts and hops.

Sampled at From The Vine beer tasting Jan 9th, 2004: This brew is a dark brown color with a thick foamy light beige head. Very thin lacing. It has an aroma of fruit, malt and toffee. Medium-bodied and rather smooth with lively carbonation. The flavor consists of fruit (plum was very noticeable), malt, and nuts. The flavors did not seem to play very well together though. The finish has a nice dark fruit character to it though. This beer is decent but I have had better Dubbels.

Reddish brown body with a tan head that quickly dissipates. No lacing.
Rich malt aroma. Some tobacco, raisins and alcohol.
Full malty flavor. Raisins, yeast and alcohol are present too. Licorice, slightly sour  and some of that tobacco among the flavors.
Full-bodied and spritzy on the tongue. Good mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2005 (Bottled, BBE 01/2006, the last bottle Ive saved from back when the Finnish monopoly, Alko, still sold this one, from De Koninck glass) Very dark brown color, slightly tanned, small but lasting head. Caramely, lightly roasted malt, hops and chocolate, dried fruit - even some rye-pudding can be found in the sweetish aroma. The flavor is well-balanced: slightly sweet, very malty and hoppy with rhum, raisins, orange-peel and a bitter, quite carbonated finish, some anisey spiciness - even banana. Long, lingering, sticky-hoppy, very enjoyable aftertaste. Quite full-bodied and carbonated, warming palate. An excellent, quite full and complex dubbel, only slightly too carbonated.

Hazy dark brown. Lovely beige head. Sweet, fruity (cherry, plums, banana) aroma w/ bubble gum & chocolate. Full bodied. Robust & sweet flavour of fruit (plums, dates, raisins), milk chocolate, banana, vanilla, licorice. Quite bitter w/ a little earthiness.

Bottle dated 27/03/03:  Ruby brownish hue; mostly clear.  About a fingers worth of foamy pale tan head.  Banana, sweet, candy, fruit nose.  Seductively sweet, dark fruit, cocoa, vanilla, cherry, licorice,  nice body, finishing with pleasant estery goodness.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2006 Deep brown and cloudy with a huge head.  Musty and old aroma of plums and cardboard.  Good palate, with the usual alcohol-like trappist flavor, and also some plum and woody characteristics.

Brown body. Not very tall, mostly lasting beige head, leaving a nice, whitish lace. Interesting notes of wine, spices and licorice. You won't remember this one for its sweetness; it's rather bitter and
hoppy. Creamy body. Very drinkable. Good stuff!
(33cl bottle) Sampled at Beerbistro in Toronto. Pours a medium, beige head and brown body. Nose of brown sugar and plums. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2004 Aroma reminds of chocolate and citrus. Fresh and invigorating. Colouring is on the dull side of dark brown.

Taste has hints of dark chocolate and fruitiness, big on malts with a dryish finish I liked.

Good stuff, but not really what I'd drink regularly.

Re-rate: it's not a remarkable beer by any means and most of my first rating still sounds right to me. Still it warranted better numbers. It doesn't feel as big to me now, but it's a very pleasant beer nonetheless.

Hazy dark brown colour with a nice off-white head. Aroma of cherries, raisins, plums and other sugars-all with a malt background. Medium to Light-bodied; Mild sweetness with strong bittering malt. Not much flavour-definately lacking-not what I had expected. Aftertaste is bland as well, not too great-only some malt showing. Overall, a nice treat, but not as good as I had expected. I got this 33 cL bottle courtesy of my sister's fiance which he got from Belgium! I sampled this one on 27-November-2003.

served from bottle dated 05/04.  Poured a lovely reddish brown with a nice toffee colored head that was quick to dissipate but left a nice thin layer at the top that lasted for much of the glass.  some good lacing.  Aroma was of dark fruits with a slight note of alcohol.  Heavily carbonated makes for a wonderful mouthfeel.  Darker fruits are carried through to the initial flavors then fades to a hoppy almost metallic finish.  This metal tatste  fades as the beer warms a bit. Very good over all.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2006 Amber brown, somewhat hazy color, great lasting offwhite head. Fruity aroma, peach, raisins, plum and some sourish notes. Some yeast. Fruity flavor from raisins and plums, nice hops and a good mouthfeel.
Old rating: 6/4/6/4/13

I must say I was really disappointed with this. The beer looked really good, with decent head retention. Aroma had the characteristic plum/Special B aroma with some banana but was mixed with a generic yeasty aroma which wasn't all that nice.
Flavour was completely lacking in malt, with a fair bit of alcohol and spice and a pretty bitter finish (for the style at least). Also a bit too highly carbonated. 
I must confess I haven't had all that many Dubbels but this falls well behind even Chimay.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 Bottled Rating 14, rerated now from tap in Brussel: :Fruity aroma, spicy, notes of plums. Fruity taste, very malty, notes of burnt chocolate and notes of cacao. Very pleasant and tasty.

Brownred with beige head.
Aroma with licorice, rubber and fruit. Smells a bit like a Riesling of good quality. 
Thin flavour, dry and malty. Tones of almonds and graphite. This one grows on you and has become a bit of a present favorite.

Light aroma. Muted malts. Some hops aroma. Pleasant but weak. Dark cloudy w/small off-white head.  Med watery body with heavy carb. Some sweetness up front. Medium heavy bitterness @ end. Nutty bitter after. Decent Belgian dubbel.
Deep brown in colour.  Aroma was slighly sweet, of bananas, some yeast and alcohol.  Flavour had a nice maltiness to it, with some citrus, smooth body.  Finishes with a slight alcohol bitterness.
Brown with a rocky tan head. A rich complex intoxicating aroma of caramel, pastries, fruit, wood and alcohol. Rich malty, yeast esthers with oak barrel flavors. A real treat to find way over here!

This beer must be evaluated at quite a warm temp. to realize its greatness.  Aroma is prunes, malt, complex.  Appearance is dead on for the style, dark brown with off white head.  Flavor is malt with yeast and a little bit of hops.  Very good ale.

On Tap in Paris! Sweet malt and caramel aroma. Dark brown, accompanied by a medium sized toffee head, with some lace.  Lovely full caramel/malt taste. Well balanced, complex and smooth as silk. Gorgeous!

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2004 Draught at The Rover, Gotehnburg, Sweden.
Brown and a little hazy. Large off-white head.
Fresh aroma, could it be pepper?
A warm alcohol-feel.
A lot of chocolate and some fruits in the flavour.

Pours a dark brown, large beige head that mainly lasts and leaves good lacing.  Aroma is lightly malty, some dough, banana, and some caramel and honey.  Flavor is quite sweet at the start, more fruity in the middle, and ending is dry.  Medium-full bodied.

Found this on tap at Gollem in Amsterdam.  The tap version is much less sweet than the bottled version.  Aroma is complex, but one of the distinct things I could detect was a fresh, harvest apple aroma.  That aroma was mildly present in the tasting also.  Very fresh and enjoyable.

Poured a cloudy dark brownish purple color with a large very light tan head with some lace.  Sweet aroma of dark fruits, in particular plums.  Taste was sweet, fruity and had hints of chocolate and roasted maltiness.
One word comes to mind... contact cement! Glue! Too bad. Seems I could have picked a better brew for my 200th!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 Unclear brown body with a foamy off-white head. The complex aroma has some fresh lemon and fruit; coffee, caramel and chocolate; some earth and oak wood.
Dry and caramelly flavour.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2003 Pure deep brown coloured with just about no head and what is there leaves fast as well. Numerous malt esters play with our nose. Dark berries and chocolate. Full mouthfeel with above average carbonation. Big malty chocolate taste, subtle hops bring us into a bitter aftertaste. It's good, but not awesome as I expected as a fierce lover of the Dubbel style.

Nice brownish red beauty. Nose is full of chocolate, fruit, slight licorice, and malt. Rich tongue fulfills more of my spicy and sweet desires with some cocoa and dried fruit. Finishes very well and leaves a pleasantly earthy taste in the mouth. Very good stuff here!
deep burgundy color with a thick white head.   Chocolate plums, mild alc, some candy, carmel a bit nutty, moderate cheese, plums dark fruit, oh man im ranting, this is fucking awsome

This beer was quite dry and at first not nearly as complex as I was expecting.  The color was solidly amber without much in the way of haze.  As it warmed up a bit it began to open up and show what it had to offer.  It picked up a hint of sweetness which helped to boost the malt perception.  There was a bit of raisin the  mouth as well as a finish that was sweet from the alcohol.  The aroma too had an alcohol component to it as well as a bit of woodiness.  Quite estery tasting without being particularly fruity tasting.  There seemed to be some higher alcohols in here as well.

Overflowed upon opening the bottle. Reddish brown maroon color. Alcohol apparent in the nose. Nutty, raisin, dark fruit, alcohol taste. Sampled at 55 degree F, alcohol seemed to be less apparent as it warmed even more.
A nice dubbel with a good color and head, great flavor, and a nose that, in my opinion, doesn't quite live up to the rest of the brew.  Overall, though, a very nice brew.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2004  Bottled.  Brown color. Off-white head. Sweet in flavor with notes of dried fruit - apricot and prune. Some juniper berry tone. Candisugary and malty. Dusty, dry finish.

11.2 oz bottle, tulip glass.  Rich brown body has traces of red.  Giant, fizzy, off-white head diminishes quickly.  Caramel/Nutty malts; flowery hops; earthy yeast.  Raisin, alcohol / solvent aromas along with some darkly sweet aromas.  Moderately sweet / lightly acidic start and a lightly sweet /lightly acidic / moderately bitter finish.  Extremely carbonated watery body.  The bottom line is: I found this to be a fairly underpowered beer.

Very dark brown color. Large head, foamy and rich. Aromas are malts, fruity, hint of banana, plums, yeasts and brown sugar. A medium bodied dubbel. Malts are rich and fruity, with chocolate and toffee tones. Yeasty and malty. Nicely balanced. A surprisingly dry dubbel. The dryness balances and highlights the fruity sweetness. Interesting effect. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
I like the Westmalle Tripel better, but this is good. chestnut brown, beige head that is very very fluffy. caramely buttery, goodness. The alcohol in this brew is a bit too harsh though.
The color is dark and brown with a beautiful brown head. The taste is a complex mix of spices, fruit and caramel.

Pours with a frothy brown head.  Deep amber color.  Yeasty, sweet(plums, brown sugar,carmel) aroma.  Soft creamy mouthfeel.  Neutral finish in terms of dryness and acidicity.  Very good Dubbel.  Thanks CaptainCougar
Murky brown color. Medium creamy beige head. Smells sweet with hint of soy. Light flavor, malt and barnyard.

Amber/brown color with some sediment, with a bubbly head that receded quickly. Floral aroma with a faint metallic smell. Flavor was slightly sweet and malty with some alcohol. Surprisingly light body, seems a little washed out or flat. Dry finish. Drink by date: 13/05/04. I think I'll secure another one from a different store and retry.
Draught. Dark brown hue with a rocky off-white head. The aroma is hoppy with traces of yeast. Good flavour which mimics the aroma.

Dark red amber with a yeasty aroma. Roast malt and caramel notes, and a high-rise, fairly tenacious head that follows the beer to the end of the glass. The taste is also richly malty and zesty towards the finish with a touch of burnt sugar bitterness.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2004 Original Rating, sometime in 2003. Bottled-Conditioned. Pleasent enough beer
Rerating, Jul 12 2004. Rich & dark, this is better than the tripel I believe. This could benefit from a little extra alcohol.

A really nice dubbel, without any traps. You don't get lost in "the Jungle of Complexity". Just a straightforwad dubbel. Colour is mahogny-brown with som haze. Lively carbonation with a dense, thick biege head which last long. Smell of dried fruit, yeast and some chocolate. Taste is very malty with a good bitterness and a medium body. Raisins and dark chocolate seem to dominate the picture. Hints of dried apricot and some banana. Some sherry-tones from the alcohol.

sunset through a sandstorm with hot cloudy hues, or dried tobacco leaf tawny burnt orange. cashew colored head is showy but too wet to lace much.  bottle says "drink before may 2004"--  hell man, i intend to drink a thousand beers before then--no worries, but thanks for the reminder.  nutty, doughy aroma, coriander tinged malts with a firm support element of alcohol.  surprisingly dry, wheat-beer dry yeastiness, somehow the palate seemed creamy and very gently brisk at the same time-- that is, a brisk bubbly feel just skipped like a stone over a velvety flow.  mandarin orange caramel deeply curtailed by dryer rough-cut tobacco flavor, like drum or samson. like "joet" says, it's alcoholic element can be characterized as tequila.  late fruitiness, leather and light sweetness comes in the last pour, with the final rush of yeast.  medium bodied, bitterness apparent immediately at swallow and lingering vividly for at least 10 seconds.  your results may vary.
A very clean dubbel.  Malt does the talking with a little fruit and alcohol notes.

Sampled on tap in Brugges, Belgium. Dark brown with about a quarter inch of tan head and a decent amount of lace. Lightly aromatic--earthy, bready, maybe a hint of bubblegum. Much lighter than I expected flavor-wise, bland even especially for a Trappist dubbel. Slight candi sugar hints. Some hoppy bitterness in the finish. Slightly thin on the palate. Good but not the best beer to illustrate the greatness of the Trappists.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2004 Pours with a large head and a dark brown color. Aroma is chocolate and raisins. Slight alcohol taste followed by some chocolate covered raisins and caramel. Fairly crisp taste and not alot of sweetness. All hail the trappist monks!

Nice head of medium sized bubbles that disappear quickly.  Very dark black/brown color that is opaque.  The nose is malty with a hint of black licorice and slightly fruity like raisins, dates, or plums.  Nice bite in the beginning that is balanced with some fruitiness, then goes to a nice long and dry finish, first sweet then bitter.  Excellent mouthfeel.  Not very fruity but I think it is better that way.  Caramel flavor more noticable toward the end.  Balanced and well made.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2004 Light brown head. Dark red-brown. Fruity,  raisiny, vinous and alcohol aroma. Malty-sweet taste with an acidic edge. Dry and slightly bitter finish. Lively mouthfeel. Complex. Not as good on draught.
Overall, this is a very good beer.  I am a big fan of Trappist Ales and this was the first one that I had, and now I'm stuck on them
Black beer with a frothy off white head, and a weak but refreshing aroma.  The flavour is malty and slightly fruity.  Overall a very pleasant, very nice beer.
Lots of carbonation. Has that horse sweat smell characteristic of Belgian Dubbels. Decent flavor similar to the taste. I was a little let down by this.

Pours a rich dark brown color with a huge fizzing head.  Floral clover and watermelon aroma supported by mellow oaky malts.  Crisp toasty malt flavor has a good yeast profile.  Body is bready with a touch of rye.  Overall, one of the best Belgian dubbels I've had.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2005 Vertical comparison between fresh dubbel and an old one, BBd 13.07.94 Above points for the fresh version. Old ones points between brackets. Colour: (Y) gushing to thick yellow-brown head, going down lacey; dark brown, mahogany shine. (O) also slight gushing to thick yellow-brown head, still lacey; very dark amber beer, quite clear at first [4]. Nose: (Y) dark malts, perfumed, alcohol. (O) vinous, malty, walnuts & raisins - a whole fruit-and-nuts cake. Complex with a lot of esters.[8] Taste (Y)Subdued bitter from fine dark malts. Ever so slight brown candi-sugar, raising with warming up. Perfumey, grassy and peppery flavour, increasing in intensity with warming towards unfermented worts. There is a retronasal hopimpression as from English hops. I have a fleeting sub-treshold of diacetyl as well, and of marzipan. (O) Nutty, oxydised flavour - a bit wild-mushroom flavour. Oxydised malt too, a bit too much roasted in character [7] Mouthfeel: (Y) well-bodied, very highly saturated. (O) Alcohol-burn, quite full-bodied. [4] Aftertaste: (Y) faint liquorice, more with warming up, slight bittering effect. (O) long prolonging of the former tastes [4] Overall: (Y) This is the surprise. This beer is actually BETTER than I remember it. Trappist ales rule indeed. (O) Somewhere the taste of the old beer derails on the overly roasted malts, whilst the nice madeirisation in the nose was promessing better. [14] I seem to have to come to the inevitable conclusion that the beer has been bettered in recent times. I know some people who are going to disagree with me...

Smells highly alcoholic and of dates and prunes.  Beautiful appearance, with a pretty lacing around the top and a dark amber body.  Fruit in the flavor, but it is a tad thin.  Dry finish.  A hint of spices and cocoa.

Small, off-white head - dark amber/crimson color - nice clarity - highly vinous, with notes of chocolate, brown sugar, raisins - slight sweetness and substantial yeast presence in the finish - very subtle and enjoyable - one of the more subdued trappist ales I've had, which is actually a good thing in this case - medium bodied, yet heavy at the same time - a must try for belgian ale lovers.
UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 aroma has a strong chocolate scent, some faint fruit and malt. Palate is thick but very drinkable, a very drinkable beer, and maybe the best dubbel out there
This is a great beer! Here in Belgium it's one of the most common trappists. Very dark brown appearance. Sweet aroma. Hints of caramel and chocolate.
Not difficult to get as other trappistes. Nice appearance, red and a big head. Good sweet and spicy aroma. Has a little fine laqurice in the flavor.

Bottled. Large fluffy brown head, that settled down but persisted throughout. Dark crimson brown (red if you hold it to the sunlight) body. Sweet nutty tasting, nutmeg and banana. Smooth enough finish.
Dark chocolatey raisiny brew, a little bit overpowered by the yeast though, not an uncommon complaint  for me. Surpisingly it was served too cold. I'd have thought the Belgian bar staff knew better.
I tasted this mighty fine trappist ale a late evening on Charlies Bar in Copenhagen. And I have been in love ever since

Clove raisin aroma. Huge tan head tops a deep rust colored body. Though sweet, this beer balances hop character well, never coming off as overly sweet. Not watery by any means, but pleasantly less thick than other Trappist dubbels. Fantastic from first sip through to finish.
wheaty orange like aroma, dark ruby colour with a large off white head, malty, chocolatey, hints of bananas, dry chocolate finish, superb.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2003 This beer is the least favourable of the trappist beers.
This Westmalle dubbel tastes a bit like Leffe bruin, great beer though.
Strong aroma of bubblegum, clove, phenol, and yeast. The flavor was more malty with a slight alcohol tinge. Nice crips feel. Dark ruby color with a large beige head.

(33 cl bottle). Enormous lasting head, cloudy brown colour. Lovely aroma of oak, leather and spices. Well balanced spicy flavour, slightly bitter finish. Aftertaste could have lasted a bit longer, but this is still a thoroughly well made beer.

Clean raisen and port wine aroma.  Murky brom in color with a foam that came rushing out of the bottle apon opening.  I belive that my bottle has been aging awhile as the date on the label says, 27/03/03 and since today is 20/03/03 I must assume that this is a "best before date" and not a "brewed on date".  Flavor is quite dull.  The effect on the palate if very creamy up front with a very pasty and almost gritty finish.  The carbonationis very fine which is nice, but due to lack of complex flavors and the strange finish I cannot rate this one to high.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2005 Nice brown color with a tan head, and it has the right amount of alcohol. Creamy and malty taste. Nicely done.

Full tan head, and a bittersweet odor hiding a hint of caramel, all of which caries directly into the flavor of this cloudy amber/brown mana. A slightly bitter finish fades to toasty goodness and seems to round out well overall. Definitely one to revisit and try variously aged versions.
A dark brown color. Alcohol and down home barn-yard flavors. Some malts and a touch of fruits.
A deep dark caramal color with moderate head. A nice amount of malty bitterness. Sticky fruits also make there presence known.

[RE-RATE] I actually had to re-rate this beer because the first time I tried, the aroma and the flavour was dominated by a sort of chemical, artifical taste (probably the bottle wasn't stored in the right way). Now I've finally drunk it on tap and there were a BIG difference. Bloody red colour. The head is big, lasting, very creamy. Chocolate, raisins and hazelnut in the aroma. Very delicate flavour, initially fruity with traces of raspberry, raisins and banana; then it becomes sweeter (chocolate and caramel) with a touch of sourness. The finish is balanced between sweet notes (hazelnut and almonds) and a light hoppy bitterness. Very good beer, perfectly balanced, pleasant and complex.
This brown baby has a big head w/ a fizzy, malty flavor. A lot has been said about it already; definitely one to try.

Well, I think it would only be reduntant to further express how great the head on this beer is, although I think this is one of the most characterizing aspects the beer has. The 2% ABV difference here versus the tripel makes a HUGE difference. Every little sweet toasty aspect of the malt is present in the flavor whereas the tripel manages to cover up half of the flavor - the yeast here also seems a lot clearer: less generic bubblegummy Belgian yeastiness, more ditinct fruity character and balance. Very nice.

A wild head on this beer, very thick.  It had a fruity, plum aroma.  This beer is very complex, yet easy to drink.  Very palatable and cool on the tongue.  Fruity taste with chocolate and yeast.  Slight notes of unripened banana.  Apples came out strong in the finish.  I also got a slight peppermint finish in the back of the throat.  A world class beer!

Bottle.  Brown appearance with a little bit of yeast visible in the bottom of the glass.  HUGE head - enough to make me wonder for a moment, but the wonderful aroma and flavor dispelled any notions that I might have a bad bottle.  Very complex taste: Cherries, chocolate, pears, cashew, woodiness all make an appearance in the flavor with apples having a cameo toward the finish.  A slightly acidic bite makes the great finish more interesting.  Truly a world-class beer.  Thank you jbrus!

330 ml Bottle conditioned ale. Dark reddy amber colour with creamy head. Still the Dubbel the others should aspire to. Natural spice flavour toasted barley and fruit (raisins). A pleasure to drink at any time.
Try to keep this for a couple of years, and you will get a delicious drier Trappist with a dark-yellow head and a fullbodied malty taste.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2003 Dark amber color, creamy head. Nice aroma of malt and hop. Very good body, malty, robust bitterness; long final, not enough aromatic; a pleasure for your taste buds!KegIt's the only Trappist beer available in kegs (and I don't understand what's the need for that). It's good but not mature nor enough hoppy; it's a bit metallic and doesn't have enough character. [7-5-6-4-13]
Very tasty intriguing Trappiste with fruity and winy palate. Some sweetish sugary notes.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2003 Large, thick and creamy beige head. Color is reddish brown color. Aroma is sweet, malty with caramel and raisins notes. Flavor is malty too, fruity (banana) with some candy sugar tones. Finish is moderately malty with a slightly spicy accent. Medium to full bodied.
This is a good Abbey Dubbel.  Flavor is sweet, malty, and hoppy.  Finishes dry with a hoppy bitter after taste.

Creamy tan head atop a dark brown body.  Aroma is sweet plum/date, some yeast, and definite alcohol.  Taste is sweet, dark fruity, and nicely malty.  Medium body, with a slight over-carbonation that detracts.  Improves significantly as it warms to room temperature.  This is a very pleasant beer, but I didn't find much depth.

Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a big tan head that lingers. It has a very attractive aroma of fruits, yeast, spices, caramel and malts. Full bodied with moderate carbonation, the flavor is malty with hints of plums, banana, yeast, and spices. The finish is somewhat dry and fruity, with a lingering sweetness. I love Belgian beers, I think that is why all my girlfriends dumped me, they couldn't compete with the likes of Westmalle and other Trappist brews. Oh well, fuck 'em, I still have my beer, and it doesn't talk back or tell me I drink too much.

A really good beer, but I had expected a great beer, like a Rochefort 10, and was so surprised when I tasted this that initially I could not write down any opionions or comments at all.  Dark reddish brown with large off-white head.  Malt with bitter finish.  Fizzy/bubbly/tingly.  A little bit more complex and more interesting as it warms, with hints of coffee and a little tannin sneaking in.  Good but there are much better Belgian dubbels, and some great American copies, at a fraction of the price.  If Unibroue decided to make a dubbel it would blow this away.  Ommegang strong ale does, and it is a fraction of the price.  Good thing I bought a case of Rochefort 10 at the same time ... on average between the two I am delighted.  ... OK ... rerate second half of bottle after it has warmed up.  Cellar temp is much too cold this week.  Warmer the beer is much more complex than I had thought, with dark malt, sweet malt, distinct flavors of chocolate, and some characteristic wheat ale spice.  Much more interesting than I thought at first.
Sparkling brown,large off white head. Fruit carmel nose. Malt flavor with slight tart finish. Fizzy

Deep burgundy-brown with a frothy and thin, yet lasting, head. "Rosy" and inviting nose. Smooth, yet tingly mouthfeel; thickish, but easy to drink; tight bubbles make it almost milkshake-like. Perfect, subtle hints of sweet candy and sour fruit. Dryish finish, but wonderful flavors (sweet, sour & bitter) reside on your tongue for some time. Not overwhelming, but very enjoyable.
one off mine favor beers
Deep brown colour, light brown/beige head.  Fruity, yeasty, molasses.  eh...could be worse, but it certainly isnt a Duinen Dubbel.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2009 Bottle  Deep brown, clear body.  Creamy, lightly brown head.  Nice aroma of malts (both crispy and burnt), fruits, wine, port, wood. Subtle but complex.  Moderately bitter, moderately sweet flavour (of malts and bit smoke).  Good balance but not very complex.  Easy drinkable.  Dryish finish.

hazy dark brown, fluffy beige head.  aroma of raisins, malt and alcohol.  small bead carbo and a smooth mouthfeel.  rich, deep  malt flavours with hints of toffee and yeast.  finishes dry.  very nice.
To be honest it doesnt rate highly on the Trappist Scale but still beats most beers hands down.
A very nice colour in the glass,A full flavor with a hint of fruit.
Deep brown color with a full, frothy head. Rich aroma was evident from quite a distance. Strong fruit and spice nose. Silky smooth going down. Warmth of alcohol lingers for a bit.

Dark ruby tint to the brown color, beautiful creamed color head, very well balanced, full bodied, lots of malty flavors, some hints of some kind of fruit flavors as well, nice well-rounded aftertaste, very good Trappist beer

WOW  mighty head, frothy and cream colored, very tightly packed.  Sweet floral nose.  This beer covers a wide spectrum of taste and delivers  with deep complexity. silky smooth The sweet floral notes fade into a nuttiness, followed by a tasty toasty  finish.  It left me wanting three or four more chances to rate it right away, just to try and spit out everything that happens.

aroma vs. appearance: the beauty and the beast, bitter fruit that goes on forever, it leaves your mouth feeling like silk, this beer left me speechless briefly until I slowly started mumbling to myself, huge fan!
Thick raisin and plum nose.  Alcohol noticable but nothing overwhelming.  Dark caramel color.  Acidic tones.  Smooth with dark fruit flavors.  Enjoyable drinking experience.
looks fantastic. amazingly drinkable, almost skullable thanks to plenty of hops and rich citric fruits to balance the rotten stone fruits
Deep and rich, but has an interesting dryness in the finish that makes one want more.  Figs plums and dark fruits abound.  The yeast is the star here, sweetish and tart at the same time.  Delectable.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2003 This beer rocks.
The aroma is very complex and interesting. Lightly floral, moderately yeasty and heavy with malt. I found traces of honey, tawny port, dough and molasses.
Dark, hazy amber hue with a large, rocky khaki head. Good lacing and mostly lasting. Delicious ale. Lightly sweet and tart. Moderately bitter. Full bodied with a lightly creamy mouthfeel. A  whisper of toffee. Fizzy. Long, dry finish. An excellent belgian ale.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 Crystal clear & shining browness.. big bubbled lather..aromas hinted at Grapes sitting in choclate autumn rain with licorice infused vinegar tartness.. Smacks of fermentation..dripping syrup of sour chocolate seeping slowly into lonely grapeseeds..terminating harshness..forgettable..weak bodied..missing sophistication

Belgian sugar taste,sweet, decent aroma, really I expected more, maybe it was what I drank previous,or maybe American Craft beers are catching up and might soon surpass many Belgians, wake up America, we are making some damn fine beer in good ole U.S.A., decent choice here,not outstanding

This was a great beer. A warm, earthy taste in the palate. Large head, beware. Alcohol is apparent, but well masked and fits the beer and style well. Intersting cloudy brown color. A good beer to just relax with. The average rating doesnt lie, try it.

Ive had this beer sitting in my fridge for days waiting to be opened.  Westmalle Dubbel did not disappoint.  Aroma was evident immeadiately after cracking the cap off.  Poured nice into a goblet with a thick head.  Beer had a consistant strong, yet smooth taste.
VERY good trappist ale. Lovely fresh aroma with a touch of bananas. A wonderful fruity (again bananas) flavour with a LONG, strong finish. A bit more dry than the other trappists I have had.

Wow.  Everything about this beer is top-shelf.  Upon opening, the beer proceeded to fizz out of the bottle.  It pours a deep cloudy umber color, with sediment collecting at the bottom.  The head pours heavy and thick, delivering an intense aroma of alcohol and apple/pear fruitiness, with hints of grape.  This beer is so complex I fear I missed half of what I was drinking.  More like a fine wine than a beer, particularly in the nose.  Character is unbelievable.  Very important to use the right glass, or at the very least, a wide lipped snifter style vessel or wine glass.  Be sure that the beer can open up and breathe to reach its potential.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2003 This beer has the typical dubbel features: its appearance is nice dark and it has sweet taste. I quite like this Westmalle version of our beloved dubbel beers!
When i opened the bottle there was a nice top of foam on the bottle, which looked so nice, appearance was worth a 5!
UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 Definitely among my favorites.  Much better than the Tripel.  Lovely candied fruit and molasses flavors.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2003 Dark brown, huge light beige head with nice lace. Aromatic and sweet malt nose. Medium to full body, bit dry, smooth. Moderately bittered, bit sweet and caramel-like, strong. Bitter, sweet, dry finish.
This pours a very nice amber/brown with a very large white head.  Very malty in character with a slight dry finish.  Worth seeking out.

While I did enjoy this one, it just wasnt quite as good as I had hoped.  The color was a bit light for me.  I like a nice opaque, dark brown color.  Too much light came through.  The aroma was very nice.  Apples, raisins, black currant, plum, and cherry.  The flavor was a bit disappointing, though, as it didnt really fit the aroma.  Dont get me wrong, this is a world class beer, but it just sort of didnt live up to the expectations.
Had a nice malty taste to it, but nothing that really knocked my socks off.  That was the first out of my sixer, Ill re-rate if necessary.

Poured in a tulip glass, exhibits a cloudy almond color with little yeast floaties.  Thick tan head which stuck around throughout the beers fragile lifespan (around me, anyway!)  Initial flavor positively explodes in the mouth.  Tons of llcorice, bubble gum, and other candy sweetness.  Above expectation hop bitterness is absolutely brilliant.  The alcohol warmth melds with the hops and sticks to the tongue.  Sweet, malty, and one of the best damn beers I have ever had the pleasure of sipping.

nice foamy head that lasts....fruity aroma and taste....alocohol lingers somewhat in the aftertaste...but still, a great beer!

rerate: slight head, mahogany brown color, fruity aroma  pear and apple in the flavor. slight spicy finish.

Wow. First taste was like someone threw a shot of Kentucky Bourbon in there. Subsequent tastes were a little more subdued possibly due to the Little Debbie Nutty Bar I was eating. Quite complex. A nice caramel nose, bubbly. Quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 Westmalle really has his own taste. Quite sparkling, but overall a good Dubbel. Additional note: Compared a 2 year old and a fresh bottle. To my surpise the two bottles didnt differ very much. The old sample was a bit more metallic and yeasty, thats all. Storing conditions were ok (no light and 10-15 degrees celcius), so i guess this one isnt really worth aging.

I actually got disappointed of this one. No actual complexity, though a clean taste of bitter chocolate and notes of fruit. Very dark compared to the strength of the flavour. Might have to re-rate it.
Rich, complex malt aroma and flavor.  Some chocolate and hints of fruit - cherries.  Well-balanced bitterness.  Good beer, however its too rich for me to drink more than one at a sitting.
I prefer this to the Triple - the alcohol doesnt overwhelm.
Nive heavy beer. A classic trappist. A little more easy to drink than eg. Westvleteren. I had this draught, which gives the beer a little more yeast-taste.

When you open the bottle start pouring, or the beer will start foaming out on the table! Nice brown lasting head. Dark brown color with quite a few bubbles of gas in it. A clear 5 on apperance! First impressions: bitter chocolate, yet sweet and fruity. Lasting not over complex taste but smooth as velvet! My favorite dubbel!
Not my favourite trappist, but there is no bad trappist (although I have not yet tried any Achel beer).  Accessible, but lacking the complexity and depth of, say, Westvleteren.

Red/brown body, frothy tannish head, decent amount of floaties.  Actually, the head is pretty incredible and lasting.  I have difficulty pointing out any specific characteristics.  Yeast, subtle malt, and a dry, slightly herbal finish.  I definitely enjoyed this one, but Im not quite able to describe how or why.  Definitely on my list to re-sample later.

Nice brown pour with a half inch tan head that stays till the end. Malty nose with some fruitiness to it. Velvety mouthfeel that makes this a pleasure to drink. Wonderful flavor not as complex as some but thoroughly enjoyable. Thanks to Indra for this one it is much appreciated.
Red/brown colour. Good lasting head. Aroma is pleasantly yeasty. Flavour is balanced and a little dry. Good long aftertaste with some bitterness. A very pleasant acquaintance.
A really nice trappist beer with a good flavour and taste.

Re-rate:  Still as good looking as ever. This time I picked put a spicey apple fruity calvados  and port wine aroma and flavour I was not able to quite pin down before. Perhaps this one was a little on the lighter side compared to the others as far as flavours go but still an damn fine beer. I also got this celery and chicken noodle soup tang thing that crops up occasionally in nearly all the trappistes - Id really like to know what that is? Everything else in previous rating stands.
 Second rating 7/7/2002 4.4 Dense brown-red murky colour with large fluffy mid-tan head, nice lacing as well. Gorgeous complex floral aromatic and spicey nose and flavours. Superb body and nicely balanced palate and finish. One of my favourite beers made even better by drinking it with a meal at an small Belgian streetcafe on a mild summers evening. 
First rated 4/5/2002 4.3
A red-brown beer with a good gead and a fruity aroma. The flavor is slightly sour and fruity. It definatly a great beer.
REd-brownish with a big head. Spicy apple-fruity aroma. Porterish apple taste. The use before date was 24.10.02. Failry old that is.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 Very good appearance. Flavor is quite heavy, bitter and a strong palate. 
Rerate (april 12, 2004) Very malty, smooth fruity aroma with raisins. Red brown coloured with a brown lasting head. Much debris. Taste is fruity (cherry ?), malty and sweet. Excellent brew. A bit my homebrew, I always have westmalle dubbels in stock. What makes this beer so great is that it never bores.. It's always great. Not many beers have this potential.
This one is a good dubble, even better than the triple.

muddy brown - reminded me of fine corinthian leather (ha ha).  Starts with a creamy carbonated mouth feel that gradually thins.  Yeasty and toffee flavors dominate with some fruitiness poppin in once in a while.  finished very dry.

A very mild and pleasant beer. Delicate and smooth mouthfeel with a very well balanced complexity. If youre not in the mood for the heavy Rochefort 10 or Westvleteren 12, this would be a great mild substitute. It is quite spicy and caramelly and the 7%ABV is not very obvious.
smooth smooth smooth.  prefect balance in palate and ingredients.  long lasting head which klings to the side of the glass.  Mmm

Great aroma, flows right though the creamy tan head. Smells flowery, bready, yeasty. Nice reddish brown color. Flavor is weaker than expected, nice mouthfeel, some caramel, musty, faintly bitter finish. What else...hmmm. The triple is better.
pleasant dubbel, balanced with rich flavors, nothing overwhelming anything else. Nice mouth-feel and finish.

Delicate nose with yeasty and raisiny aromas. Brown base color with a slight red tinge. Nice tan leggy head. Sweet flavor up front that is spicey, nutty and has hints of honey. There is a woody finish that is slightly dry. Nice boost of taste from the alcohol. Complex palette. Mature and well-balanced. Enjoy this best by itself.
Malty with raisin, honey, molasses and vanilla aroma. Nice amber with a light brown head. You taste alcohol and spicy peppery malt. Kicks on the tongue and has a long lasting finish. Nice...!
Hmm, i was suprised by this one, because people always talk about Westmalle triple. Beautiful color, a little sweet, chocolate. A nice beer.

Somewhat subtle aroma, noticeable alcohol and warm banana bread.  Lovely color, persistent thin butterscotch head, and lasting carbonation in mouth.  Rich flavors, but not sharp in any, with a warm dry bitterness in the finish.  It evolved nicely as it warmed up.

sense ruddy brown colour, frothy bubbling head than quickly subsides to nothing. complex sweet and spicy aromas.
detect flavors of milk chocolate, apples, caramel and several herbal notes.
this beer gains depth as it warms.
another great trappist.
Beautiful touches of chocolatey malt and flowery hop bitterness…Candied apples and light citrus fruit sorbet…Much better in the bottle than on tap…
nice beer to drink when it is cold outside
Full-bodied. Fruity, warming with an almost salty bitterness.

Excellent with a little dinner, after a hot, hard day. 
Still marvellous (04/2002 )
Same thought (06/2002)

UPDATED: APR 16, 2003 I found this to be somewhat medicinal.  It did little for me.  I tasted a lot of flavors, and it was a truly malty beer.  A bit disappointed.  A little bitter, too, though the aroma hints of sweetness that wasn't there.

Dark brown color, good head.  Chocolat and dark fruit in the aroma with a touch of alcohol.  Dark fruit tastes carry into the body, finishes hoppily bitter.  Nice warming alcohol.  Overall this is a very nice beer, perhaps I expected more?  Regardless, top notch.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2003 Dark reddish mahogany color, fine-bubbled and very persistent head.  Aroma is quite complex, having some various dark and sweet fruits, a slightly medicinal component, and some dark sugar.  Flavor is also quite complex, with the sweet-bready malty flavors dominating, but also a touch of wine.  Creamy mouthfeel for such a style.  Spicy and interesting yeast flavors in the finish.  Medium bodied.  I tried it both before and after I swirled and poured the yeast.  The yeast added a bit of nuttiness and sharpness to the finish.  Incredible lacing, this is an attractive beer, and a very nice one all around.  Unique.
Nothing needs to be said about this beer. Its reputation preceeds it.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2003 Cloudy brown color, average frothy, clingy off white head. Has a bready yeasty banana aroma. Sweet malty doughy flavors of
dark fruits
such as plum and rasions, medium body with a light bubbly mouthfeel, it finishes rather dry, which is a good thing, not the best trappist but still great.
Very malty body with notes of chocolate. Finish is rough on the palate. Aftertaste lingers in an unpleasant manner. Complex but way out of balance.

I have to be honest when i say that im undewhelmed by the Westmalle beers. The dubbel was very malty with a load of chocolate, soft fruit, and a sharp alcohol bite. The finish was off though, not quite sure how but definately off...
A great beer.  Cant tell any appreciable difference in the bottle or tap version.  Thre are no tours of the Abbey, but there is a cafe accross the street that is an excellent place to have a few.
I am in Belgium trying all the different Beers here and this is the best I have had yet.  It is just a well rounded beer with a great taste, it has stood out of all the other trappist I have tried
Pours with an impressive head.  A smooth foamy mouthfeel adds to the experience.  This hasnt got the coffee/chocolate notes that Rochefort8 has.  Nevermind - its still a great beer.
This one does nothing for me, the head is small and the aroma and flavour seem to be lacking. Next dubbel please.
Very dark, with full malty, raisiny, curranty and alcohol aromas and a mellow, smooth, but rich dark malt palate.

This rating is based on the exellent Westmalle Dubbel draught beer served in Carlsens Kvarter, Odense, Denmark. Fruity aroma, dark colour, it is fruity and deep in its flavor. Truly a magnificent trappist ale.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2007 Best before June 09.

Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, milk chocolate, nuts, cookie), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), lightly hoppy (flowers), with light notes of raisin, plum, brown sugar, cinnamon, alcohol.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Solid but short of awesome.
Best when fresh on draft
Nice creamy, bready, malty Trappist ale.  Big head but quickly diminishes (good thing as far as Im concerned).  I like this much better than the trippel.
Rich aroma with strong tones of apple. A highly complex taste with a blend of cherry, apple, and chocolate. Quite dry in the finish. An excelent beer.

A fun beer to watch.  Small bubbles that get bigger as you go up in the tall amber head.  An amber orange color.  Quite dry.  Noted the darker fruits including cherries.  A dry finish with flavors of hazelnut and toast.

I really dont know how to explain what I tasted in this beer, it was so complex, so much going on. Had a terrific aroma of a fine after dinner drink. The appearance was dark brown and reddish. The finish was dry and fruity. I absolutely love this beer.
Chestnut brown in color,smooth and complex,rich with malt falvor,fruity,bread and biscuit aroma/flavor.

Dark, Dark orange-red/ looks like blood; Head was thin but fizzy; Aroma was full of Cognac and alcohol. Alcohol fills the mouth. Still very Cognac-like in the mouth. Also surprisingly dry, but not floral like an Orval. Very little sweetness or grapiness that i might have expected from this style. Palate was a bit thin.

I had a difficult time putting my finger on what exactly was happening in this beer.  Saying that, I will definitely revisit and hopefully be able to appreciate this beer more.  My bottle had incredible carbonation and poured with a nice head, although it did not last very long.  Eventually a thin bead of foam persisted.  The color is very attractive: a red rust/dark copper color.  The aroma is quiet malty.  I found the beer to be seemingly bitter, malty, and slightly yeasty.  The aftertaste was very dry, and I was left with a slightly fruity sensation.  I enjoyed this beer, but need to take some more time with it in the future.

A soft fruity and still-baking bread nose with a bit of an oak barrel alcohol aroma. Very complex taste as I expected with a very, very smooth finish.  I poured the entire contents into my brandy glass and was surprised at how much the yeast at the bottom resembled tobacco bits. I pledge to have this on tap at least once in my lifetime.
This is my no. 1 beer

The ultimate beer in every aspect. Dip your nose into its beautiful foam as soon as you can and lose yourself in the image of the old Belgian monastery where the monks probably lead a very satisfying existence.
had it on tap in Oldenzaal. Taste of burned malt, fruity (apple, raisin), yeasty. Complex like almost all trappist ales. A bit sweeter than when bottled.

Tremendous. Similar in body to St. Feuillen; spritzy but still full enough to let the flavors shine through. And the flavors!...a little raisin, plum, tart cherries. Malty, yeasty (but not too much), just a great dubbel. Incredibly rocky, off-white head that lasts and lasts.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Cloudy brown color, dark beige head, and sheets of lace. Nose is lightly tinted with banana, slightly sour, hints of malt. Front is malt, the top light, the finish dry, nicely hopped, acidic with moderate carbonation, and hints of alcohol bitterness also noted.
A lovely red colour, with an excellent palate which lasts for a while.  Good strength and bitter flavours make for a lovely Belgian.

A dark with a tan persistent head. Herbal like tequila, toffee, hints of bubblegum. Back is softened hops and the feel is very nice creamy laced with alcohol heat. Its on the drier side of abbey ales and thats a very good thing.

My perfect beer - I really don’t see what fault you could find in a beer like this, truly wonderful stuff, makes you wonder what the monks do after quaffing a few of these, but this beer has a nice, pronounced head that never disappears, a beautiful brown appearance with a touch of red, and for me, just an amazingly creamy texture, a sweet flavor, it’s unbelievably complex with a long, long, satisfying finish.  I would recommend this beer to anyone.  I ask you, what more could you ask for?

Beautifully chestnut brown colour, hazy and crowned with beige head. Slightly bubble-gum/banana estery nose. Balanced sweetness and soft maltiness turning into a dry, hoppy finish. These Trappist monks know their stuff, but its not as good as, say Westvleteren. But then - what is?
in my opinion there is a difference between tap en and bottle

very good 

strong alcohol taste

have to let it warm to room temp to really enjoy
Damn this was a good beer.  One of the best belgian ales I have ever had.  Beautiful color and gorgeous head retention.

Pours with a huge, rocky head. Has a deep red color. Strong scent of red wine, and it delivers a similar flavor. Almost too much effervescence to be really enjoyable, and I tasted a good deal of sourness alongside alcohol and some slight woody tones. Ill have to try another bottling to see if the sourness is characteristic, or if I got a flawed batch.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Spicy aftertaste, pleasant nose.  Pours a deep reddish-brown with a medium-sized off-white head. Aroma is candy sugar, malt and dates.
A very nice, smooth drinking beer. Nice head and Belgian Lace! The yeast spiciness does tend to hide some of the other flavors but Id still get a case if I could.
Wow! Worth every gilder or Euro. good luck finding this at Walmart. Very close to a much easier to find Chimay(Blue). The monks put out a great product.
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2003
Pretty good, i would definatly have this again, but not at the $4 price i paid for it.

Very powerful banana, yeast and chocolate aroma emminating from a deep brown beer with a frothy, light brown head.  Malty with dark fruits and chocolate up front, thin and watery in the middle and dry, spicy and hoppy in the finish.  Interesting progression through the flavor profile.  Thin body really spoiled this for me - seemed as if something was missing.  I agree with Shadallion that Rochefort is vastly superior.

A simple but ok dubble.
Not the best, but certainly not the worst.

As a classic Belgian dubbel, it reinforces why they are not my favorite beers.  Excellent aroma, but the body is thin and over-carbonated.  Yes, it should be, I know.  I just feel if Im drinking a 7% alcohol beer, I should get more flavor and body because Im only going to have one or two.
A great example of Belgian trappist ale.
Aroma dominated by alcohol and wort,long lasting head and  complex flavours of nuts caramel and chocolate.
Very nice dubbel. Banana/plum/yeast heavy in the nose. Wine/chocolate taste. Hoppy finish. Enjoy!

Bottle sampled in 2001 (no bottling date but prob 2000-01).  Deep red-brown color with medium-thickness head; strong grapy aroma with I think a hint of cloves.  Flavor very wine-like but with enough malt and hops so you know its beer; I personally loved it.  Goes down very smooth; one of the most drinkable, quaffable Belgians, if not the most complex.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 Strong plum/wine aroma. Powerful head that leaves a nice lace.  Slight lingering alcohol aftertaste.  The taste of dark fruit is surprisingly good.  The bottle that I had was 10 months old.  The next one I get will be aged for at least two years.
Fruity, and very long. A very good beer. This one is special to me, since it was the first belgian ale I ever tasted...years ago. I have tasted better examples later, but..
Banana and yeasty aroma. Beautiful head. Dark brown colour. Malt sweetness, hoppy. Finishes a little bitter. Best on tap.

Yeasty but subdued aroma, the weak point of this beer.
Reddish-brown with a sturdy yellow/slightly brown head of foam of good persistance, with a steady stream of bubbles feeding it.
Good malty and hoppy flavor with good body and intensity.
Mellow start with a long lingering in the mouth, not sweet, culminating in a balanced and hoppy but not too bitter finish.
Trappist?  You bet!  Not only an excellent brew, its food, too!

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2004 11.2 oz bottle:
Soft body, a malty and chocolatey flavor and some fruit as well. Rather dry at the end with spicy hop notes. Nice.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Fantastic!  A real eye opener, great texture and colour with taste to match.
Heaps of chocolate, banana, and raw alcohol. Dig it a lot.

its great, theres no doubting that. Rich in flavour, and lovely dark appearance. i think that my rating would have been affected by the weather (it was hot), but i still thought it pleasant to drink, but i will be retasting it, theres no doubt about that.
Very dark brown, with beige head. Intense junipery, licorice aroma.  Dense flavors of ripe fruit and licorice dominate the taste.  Decent, but Rochefort and Westvleteren are vastly superior.

At first glance, I thought this was a glass of root beer. Very large bubbles throughout, and a thick, creamy, tan head. The aroma reminded me of lemon zests (rinds), and almost a odd cleanser-like (pine-sol) smell. Very smooth considering how bubbly it is. The taste is very subdued, with subtle hints of citrus (orange, lemon, tangerine?), spices and a root beer aftertaste. Toward the finish a bitter-sweet taste that is reminiscent of hops evolves. Different, and good. Possibly my favorite trappist, and far superior to its Westmalle Trippel cousin.

This is, thus far, the most unique of the trappists Ive tried (unless you consider the cough syrup taste of Orval unique). Let me qualify that by saying unique in a positive sense.  This has the largest bubbles I have seen; big and coarse, the bubble rise through the cloudy brown liquid like coca-cola. Thick  beige head.  The aroma instantly reminded of honeydew melon.  Extremely smooth, especially in consideration of the carbonation.  Subtle, mellow taste includes melon and orange-rind.  Very little alcohol presence.  My second favorite Trappist...a delight!

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2003 Rerate of slightly aged version:
Bready/woody aromas, raisiny esters.
Reddish, cappucino head.
Taste is spicy, estery, 
toffee and raisins. Somewhat weaker old than in a fresh version, especially the bananalike flavors and aromas are gone. The body is not as deep as it could be, finish is actually a bit weak.
The head on this stuff is incredable, a full firm 1.5 over the rim. And the flavor is so complex, lots of malt and hops. Very well balanced, one of the best doubles available.
Not one of the better dubbels Ive tried, but still pretty good.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2004 dark brown colour, fine creamy head, complex aroma of malt, apple and caramel, full-bodied, moderately sweet with a dry and long malty and slightly fruity finish

UPDATED: APR 12, 2004 Oh my God, nearly a perfect beer. Its a perfect balance of fruity malt flavors and a firm and pleasant hop base. Lightly dry. The malt/hop balance is as noticeable in the aroma as it is in the flavor. Dark ruby-red tinted brown.

Years later, an update, and how interesting how things have stayed the same: my main note from the new fresh tasting is that this beer is exquisitely balanced. The sweetish almost nutty malt flavors mingle with a lightly hopped dry finish, all the while swimming with the lightest phenols (banana) and no alcohol presence whatsoever. Maybe its not distinctive, but its a great beer that does not draw attention to itself. I'm lowering my numbers from 4.8 only because I think the original score was a tad too high, not because my opinion of it has dropped.
